description:
went out to eat with grandparents and they had decided on this one. There's like three or four restaurant to each side of this restuarant, guess this place was special? Who knows..

I got there early so I sat inside to wait for my grandparents, inside wasn't full, half the tables were full. Once my grandparents arrived we head to the inner area which had more tables, and again less than half the tables had people.

We order the usual and felt the foods were meh, nothing special, common food like most of the restuarant in chinatown. We ordered shui mai, shrimp rice roll, fried donut roll, shrimp dumpling and some more that I forgot what it was. We also ordered a fried vermicelli dish that had way too much oil, it did tastes good but just too much oil.

Overall, price is okay, nothing popped for the food. Could have chosen some other restuarant, maybe tried out the Begoni Bistro.
author: Jen M.

description:
I had a deal on Yelp for free potstickers, and at first they honored it. Then, they turned around and change their minds? This is coming from the manager too. That's bad already. 

Also, this place was way too crammed. Any yem cha (dim sum) place would be, but this one is way too much.  Food was good though, but not coming again.
author: Jocelyn C.

description:
Ate here with my parents recently. Chinese people love fresh seafood, so my mom asked them if they would steam a live fish that she had purchased in Chinatown elsewhere and had cleaned. They said yes and charged us $10 for it. Apparently, Begoni down the street does it for $15. The fish turned out perfectly steamed with soy, scallions, ginger and cilantro (traditional preparation).  We also had giant clams (very fresh but not much meat), hot and sour soup (a little bland), garlic snow pea shoots (vines were too mature so kind of tough and too oily), shrimp with bok choi (kind of boring and shrimp were too salty), longevity noodles (just right), and salt and pepper pork (not enough salt). Overall, food was mediocre but service was great.

If you come for dinner and if there is no car parked in their loading zone, you can ask the owner if you can park there even if there is a cone there. They won't tow or ticket you and you save yourself some headache of trying to find a parking spot in Chinatown!
author: Jeff K.

description:
Ahhhhhh...Chinatown.  So many places to shop and walk about and even more places to eat.  Walking around mid-day, you get famished and want some really good Dim Sum.  

Passing restaurants by restaurants and even some people passing out menus and flyers at the corner of the streets inviting patrons to their place.  One place was a 100+ year old restaurant.  Lots of choices but so many bad reviews for most of them.  I went into a more modern and busy place and I basically walked out after hygiene was a serious issue - I witness things...I saw things...things I can never un-see!  Brrrr.....!

Ended up at Peninsula and ordered a bunch of my old favourites.  HaGow, SuiMai, ChunFun, Meat Balls...so good to get good old cantonese DimSum.  I don't mind the dumpling and all that XLB stuff, but it's good to get things I grew up on.  My Cali-Friend finally got to have the ChunFun.  Never had it, always wanted to try.

This is a standard spot.  You know.  Walk in and get a tiny piece of paper and wait.  Finally a person screams out in a language that I don't understand but I kind of know numbers.  It's like...Bingo!  You jump out and eagerly walk to a table you know has worn out seating and question the cleanliness of the worn out carpet.  But you turn a blind-eye to it cause you're gonna get some FUD!  The place is actually larger than it looks.  The front is small but as you walk towards the back, it opens up to a larger seating area.

Food was average.  Nothing to jump up and down.  What you get out of the whole thing is you ate dinner in historic Chinatown in SanFran. 
Need a lot more than that for me to return to this place as again, so many places to try.

Cheers.
author: Peter M.

description: If it were possible to give negative stars, this review would be it. The shrimp dumplings we ordered were raw and cerlantro shrimp dumplings seemed to be off. We ended up cancelling the dishes. This was made worse by the fact that the waiters were also very rude. Not coming back!
author: Tim W.

description:
Several years later and after moving back the Bay from LA my family and I still come here regularly for dinner and dim sum. Like I  said previously, this place cater to the local clientele and for some (non Cantonese/non-mandarin speakers) there may be a language barrier that affects your experience. It's not a fancy place and honestly it reflects the service style of most Asian establishments. 

Peninsula seafood excels with their dim sum dishes in the AM and if you're able to come with a friend that speaks Cantonese and/or knowns Cantonese cuisine in the evening, you're able to get a great dinner with delectable seafood dishes at night, family style.  They are great with their giant steam clams, fresh steamed fish, clay pot rice, and an assortment of peppered flavor pork ribs. Etc. One dish we love is their egg battered, peppered crab similar to the ones at R&g lounge. Of a note, all seafood items (ie. Fish/crab/lobster) are priced by the lb. this is consistent with most establishments so be mindful when you order. 

For dim sum the standard hai gow and shu mai are made perfectly. I've heard they have amazing clay pot Rice and their egg tarts are on par. Like all dim sum restaurants you're charged the standard fee /person for tea. I noticed some reviews mentioning that. Let's be real, ALL dim sum restaurants do this..even your beloved Koi palace in Daly City. 

So if you don't mind the language barrier and diving into something new. This is your place. Be nice. Be courteous and research ahead which canto dish you want. They're likely have the standard Americanized Chinese dishes like beef and broccoli, sweet and sour pork, general Tso chicken as well haha. I know since my brother and I order those dishes as second generation Asian Americans.
author: Diane T.

description: After exploring Chinatown for the day, I walked past this restaurant and began speaking to one of the owners who was standing outside of the building. They went over the menu and I decided to give it a try. I ordered the Steam BBQ Pork Bun and their spring rolls. I highly recommend this spot
author: Brad D.

description: Was looking for some familiar flavors as we explored China Town.  Had been wandering around for a while and decided to give this place a try.  Had a couple staples... Fried beef noodle, preserved salted fish and chicken fried rice and the adventure item...a salt pepper beef ribs.  The flavor was nice but some pieces were a bit tough.  Might try again... Felt very familiar with is nice.
author: William L.

description:
Came for dinner and it was good.  
They accept credit cards for payment.

SERVICE: - 4/5
Service was good.  The servers were very nice and attentive.  They even changed our plates for us.  We asked for iced water and they brought us a pitcher of water.  

I didn't order so whatever food came to our table was a surprise.

FOOD:
- Fried Spareribs with Spicy Salt and Pepper - 5/5
The pork chops were deep fried just right and crispy.  The salt and pepper was very delicious.  

 - Steamed Chicken with Ginger Sauce - 5/5
Half a chicken.  Very good.

 - Sauteed Gai Lan (vegetable) - 5/5
Very good.

- Beef and Bok Choy - 4/5
Dish was tasty.

 - Lobster with Vermicelli and Napa Cabbage. - 3/5
Subtle lobster flavor.  Lobster didn't have much meat.  The vermicelli was tasty but a little too soft.  

 - Clams with Black Bean Sauce - 3/5
There were about a dozen clams.  Need more clams, but the sauce was delicious.  

 - Squid with Mixed Vegetables - 3/5
The squid was good.  The mixed vegetables are celery, carrots, straw mushrooms and snap peas.  Need more of the other vegetables besides all the celery. 

Would return to this restaurant.
author: J W.

description: Went here yesterday for dim sum and will not be coming back.  The hostess at the front ignored us even though we were standing in front of her and took the names of everyone else who spoke Cantonese first . Once we were seated, no one came to get our order for food or drinks for about 30 mins. We had to flag one of the staff members down to take our order.  I tried to also ask for chili oil because I love chili oil with my dim sum, but the waiter rudely said no without me even finishing my sentence.  I wish I got that waiters name. He was terrible and looked like he hated his job. Anyways the food did not taste that great and service was super shitty. Be warned if you're going to this dim sum place (esp if you don't speak Cantonese).  Go down the street instead, there's plenty of other places with better service and dim sum.
author: Bee R.

description: It was not our first destination but we walked in since they have porridge which I long for due to stomach sickness. The staffs are super nice. We order chicken porridge，beef with chinese broccoli（asked for less oil and they make it！）and sweet potato leaves，all are nice apart from the beef. I have a pretty comfortable dinner.
author: Viki C.

description: We were waiting 4 person tables. Host keep letting other cut in front of us.  Food wasn't good.  Is very dirty everywhere.
author: Wing L.

description:
Food is good except seafood. Servers didn't speak much. The mushroom pork dumplings are great, but I got the shrimp dumplings and as I took a bite, I realized it smelled and tasted kinda weird, but I didn't know if I was just eating more traditional Asian food, so I kept eating. It smelled and tasted like raw fish that has been sitting out for too long. Unfortunately I ate 1 dumpling, than thought it could be a fluke and took a bite of the next dumpling. Nope! Now my tummy hurts!! (Hours later) I think my stomach is stronger than some others too, it rarely ever hurts. If you want seafood go next door. There might be a little bit of a wait, but at least you won't get food poisoning.

Also, the bill is hard to understand. It's scribbles and then a price.
author: Patty A.

description:
Located next to a highly rated Dim Sum restaurant that did not open and looks 'out of business'.

Dim Sum was pretty good. Prices were on par with the other place.

All the regular menu items: Shrimp Dumplings, Pork Dumplings, Char-su Bao. You can order your food by marking a list of items or wait for the carts to deliver it. We chose to order our items and dishes were brought out promptly. $1 is charged for a glass of water or tea. This restaurant mainly serves the locals (Chinese) and only one young waiter could speak English fluently. Keep expectations in check with service. The food is pretty good and the experience of eating real Dim Sum is something you will remember.
author: Manny F.

description: The food was very tasty, lots of variety for dim sum.  The service was great, very attentive and fast
author: Randi W.

description: Chinese... everytime I get enthused about Chinese food, and am generally disappointed... this was sadly no exception. In fact this has put me off for some time. The service was very average, the food bland and not nice at all. Should have explored the area more for a better option.
author: Alena K.

description: Horrible customer service. We were seated and the waiter never came back to take our order. 20 minutes went by and a family were seated next to us and the waiter took their order but never took ours! Will never return.
author: Pamela G.

description: They charge you tips without notice or your agreement. The dish name does not comply with the content. They used some onions, pepper as wild veggies  (野三鲜)
author: J J.

description: Really good, very authentic dim sum. Note this is a locals place, with a mostly senior citizen clientele. Few staff members speak English, but everyone was helpful. Great baked pork buns, dumplings, etc.
author: Jordana G.

description: These people don't know good customer service, the waiters don't even know English so they couldn't explain the menu to us and our main dish came before the appetizers. So we had to cancel the order of the appetizers because we had already got our main dish so there was no point of the appetizer. WAY overpriced. Don't waste your time here.
author: Abigail G.

description: Poor customer service!!! Food is very average!! Please be aware of that if you paid via credit card/debit card, you will be charged 15% gratuity  automatically regardless how many people you have!! It make sense if it was party of six or more however in this case, it was not even legal to do so! Please do yourself a favor and visit another restaurant
author: Mei M.

description:
Disgusting. Tea cups and teapots are disgustingly dirty. Ordered bbq pork and my wife got beef and broccoli. After one bite my wife almost threw up. So we didn't even eat the food. When asked for a check the server didn't even say what was wrong, since both dishes were untouched. He gave me the total of $37, I gave him my $40 and took off. 
Not coming back to this s..t hole.
author: Kos N.

description: bad restaurant i have ever eaten qnd expensive for the Dim sum they charge $7 for Siu mai and $6 for 1 Har Gow unbelivable also the taste was no good. Not recommend for the tourist eat in this restaurant. P/s: becareful what u guys are going to order make sure check the price first.
author: Shu O.

description:
Dim sum was mediocre and over priced. Honestly, I don't know why it's so hard to find decent dim sum in SF. Maybe I should have done more research on Yelp, but I was starving after running the SF Marathon and was willing to eat ANYTHING! Penninsula looked promising enough as the restaurant was packed and there were even people waiting. Since we were only a party of 2, we were seated immediately. Here you order off a menu (not the carts), but we were told some of our choices were already sold out. 

The food came out very hot, but it just wasn't as good as some of the dim sum I have in LA. Dumplings were doughy, radish cakes didn't have sauce, few shrimp in the rice rolls, etc. Service wasn't great, but it was along the lines of pretty much any other Chinese restaurant. The whole place just has an old and grimy feel to it. If you're looking for an alternative, maybe check out the place a couple doors down that Obama went to.
author: Jennifer A.

description:
Morpheus: This is your last chance. After this, there is no turning back. You take the blue pill - the story ends, you wake up in your bed and believe whatever you want to believe. You take the red pill - you stay in Wonderland and I show you how deep the rabbit-hole goes.
The Matrix

You stand in the line out the door at Great Eastern and you know that whatever you order will be very good to excellent.  You walk into Peninsula Seafood and you don't know how good your food will taste.

Inside Peninsula is split into 2 large dining rooms.  The wait staff is very efficient and the food comes pretty fast.

Bbq pork pan fried noodles featured egg noodles with a very distinct flavor.  The bbq pork and bok choy was very good.  Good flavorful dish.

Bbq pork buns were a bit on the small side and I would prefer more chunks or slices of pork inside.  The pastry part had a light flavor.  Very good using San Diego dim sum ratings.

Har gow was very large and full of delicious shrimp flavor.  Excellent dish!

Sui mei was large and just had pork flavor.  Good dish.

If you don't like standing in a long line to wait for a table this is the place for you.
author: Soo H.

description:
BEWARE TOURIST!!Stopped at this restaurant on the way home from the airport. Took a long time for someone even acknowledge us at the table. A lady passed by with a cart with dumplings and basically forced us to pick one. She kept just pointing to the menu saying something in cantonese. We thought maybe it was included in our lunch so accepted. They were actually really good. 
 Once the waiter came over to ask us what we wanted, we ordered the sea bass steamed, house special rice, and general chicken. The waiter brought over a nice looking fish. Said it was 2 pounds. We accepted. The prices for that were obviously not posted on the menu for the fish. The waiter then came back and starting writing on the back of our ticket. Put down the prices of the 3 dishes. I understood $50 total. I thought no problem. It was $50 just for the fish!!!  Sea bass. Not Lobster. Then when we go the final bill it came out to $101 for lunch. I asked the waiter to explain. $2 per person just to sit at the table. $1 for a glass of water per person, and the waiter felt the liberty to include his tip as well. Probably hoping we would not notice and give him more. When I asked to see the fine writing for these fees, he asked if we were tourists. Like it was ok to rip off tourists. I didnt leave him a tip for being sneaky and I am positive the fish did not cost that much. I could understand charging a fee for the table if we just bought tea or something. It was only myself and my husband and still ended up spending $90. I looked around at the other people's bills on the tables as we were leaving and they were not even close ours, but they were all asian and could understand the writing and the language.
author: Meticulosity C.

description:
When I was planning a trip to San Francisco, a stroll by Chinatown was on my mind. We came to Chinatown around noon and 'hangry' was just about to start creeping up on me so we decided to find some quick bites. Couple of dim sum we stopped at were take out only, then we came across this spot.

The place was busy but the wait for a table was quick, we were seated in about 5 minutes. Every table that was occupied was with Chinese locals, a good sign. This was the real deal.

After we ordered some items on the menu and we're waiting, servers were walking around with other food items and would stop by our table with it. We got some items from them as well.

I enjoyed all the dim sum items we got. My favorite were the pork buns, the shrimp and cilantro  dumplings, pork and rice rolls, and the egg custard. All seemed fresh and were delicious!

It was a good sign when most of the people dining in were Chinese and our need to grab delicious quick bites were met!
author: Yukta R.

description:
Dim sum all day...well, most of the day, but definitely early in the morniing! 

We were looking for a dim sum place that starts serving in the morning since this was our last day in the City. We asked one of the staff members at a nearby hotel and this was the place they recommended. 

#foodielicious

The dim sum is on point! I couldn't read anything...so thank goodness they had a menu that had some English words so I could try to make sense of the menu. I picked out the things that I knew I liked, but I really relied on my friend who could speak a bit of the language. 

What to order? I loved the siu mai, of course, that is always my go-to at dim sum restaurants. The sticky rice with meat on the insider wrapped in leaves is tasty! one of the best I have had. I enjoyed the shrimp fun roll and the egg plant stuffed with shrimp, but my favorite...that was the dessert! The bun with egg custard was the best I had ever had...the bread was so soft and baked perfectly. And the egg tart came out fresh and that is how it should always be eaten. The best!

I'm craving the egg custard bun right now...if I could be back in Chinatown tomorrow morning, I would order a half a dozen of these tasty buns! If you are near there and enjoying some dim sum, please have an extra one for me!
author: Grace B.

description: Decent dim sum with servers that don't pay much attention to you despite being the only customers there. Wonton soup was pretty good too but nothing special.
author: Mei C.

description: We stopped in for dim sum on a Sunday morning. We arrived just before 11am and the wait was 30 min for a table of five. It turned out to be 45 min to get our table, but it was worth it! The food is really good, and you get served very fast. The Siu Mai was delicious and the spring rolls were amazing. Everything was good! Next time I want dim sum in the city, this will be my first choice! Yum!
author: Cathy O.

description: Horrible experience at this restaurant. Service was poor and food was akin to below average Take-out fare. Very disappointing!
author: Alison C.

description:
Desperation.....  leads to poor results!

We ended up here for two reasons:
1.  Hunan Homes had a long line-  even at 2pm.
2. My son desperately needed to use the bathroom.

If only I had read yelp I would not have stepped foot in this restaurant.  "POOR FOOD SAFETY"... thank you Yelp!

First of all, they bring you a pot of tea without even being asked for it and then you are told that it was an extra $5 when you inquire about your bill.

Second of all, the rice is not included with your meals.  It is $2 a small bowl.  That pertinent info is also not disclosed anywhere until you review your bill and demand an explanation of why your anticipated $70 bill is now $13 more!

Third....  you are eating your meal with the smell of cigarette smoke and also of the pollutants from the street.  

When using the restroom the woman who was cleaning it was banging and yelling in Cantonese at the person that was inside.  If I was the one inside the restroom I would have been horrified.

Service is non existent.  The food is mediocre.
Poor health inspection report....  pricing is not transparent.

All reasons to NOT enter these doors, but instead to wait in line at Hunan Homes and tell your children to use a bathroom before you leave the house!
author: Anne W.

description:
Went here a quick early lunch (11:15) but quick it wasn't.  Place was very busy so we figured "how bad could it be?"  As with many restaurants in Chinatown, service is lackluster but at this place it was nonexistent.  If a server hadn't strolled by with a plate of chow fun we wouldn't have gotten any food at all.  Finally got some dim sum and the food tasted good.  But nowhere were any prices posted so you didn't know if you're overcharged or not.

Overall this place is ok but I wouldn't hurry back.
author: Wil C.

description: Food was pretty good not the best we've had but good, service was great, we only had 30 min to eat and it was perfect for being on a rush
author: Melissa P.

description:
Me and my family came out visit my husband grandma in chinatown she told us this place was good we gave it a try.
We order
Black bean baked oysters- really flavorful a little salty goes with well with white rice.

Quail- so oily no flavor
Honey walnut shrimp- gross taste like maynoise.
Fish maw soup- taste just right with the flavor you, don't have to add anything.
Baked clams- really good and on point.
Overall the food was decent and the price we pay $74 for all that. Next time if i go back i would want to try other stuff on the menu. It's in chinatown and not that crowded big space so i like that.
author: Hoa T.

description: A Chinese Restaurant that serves Seafood. This place serves mostly local chinese.  We understood some of the dishes as they were called out when the wait staff brought trays of food to the tables.  The staff does speak English so not to worry. The restaurant was recommended to us by local store clerks so we knew we were one to a find. Order some noodles and some dim sum.
author: Garry Y.

description: Note to self; never eat here again! Service was awful. Ordered 2 items along with the other 8 we ordered and it never came. Lady never bothered to even tell us they were out of it or offer a substitute. Gentleman behind us yelled at her for the awful service he also received.  Not impressed by food. Should have followed other Yelp reviews and went some where else. To top it off, we had a party of 4, she added a $12 gratuity with no notice on the menu or signage! Rip off we got it back and she got No Tip for being an awful server and being sneaky. I think its illegal too so be aware......Double check your check!
author: Yvette K.

description:
Absolutely the rudest restaurant that I have ever walked into. No customer service, very degrading to people with children and absolutely rude. Extremely small variety for dim sum after 3
Didn't even bother tried to leave and the manager tried to charge us for 5 dollars a table. Do not step into this place you will regret it!!! After we left my mother forgot  her sweater and than when we went back in to find it somehow it magically disappeared. But i think we all know what happened to it.
author: Por V.

description:
Dim sum pretty good .. the chicken claw was very tasty. The deep fried dumpling always good. Just didn't have much of a menu since we dined after 3 pm but gosh it did take forever for our food to come. 

Service was poor and bad that's usual in Asian restaurants like these so I'm not surprised and I don't really care. Not expecting super, great, or even good service or anything to that level when I'm in areas like this. But I love China town though, so traditional and interesting to explore. 

Anyways the restaurant wasn't inviting or clean. Especially the restrooms smh yuk.
author: Marie C.

description:
We got the first family dinner for 4 people, my mom is vegetarian so she got one vegetarian rice noodle plate


Pros:
-no lines
-decent size with enough space between tables
-food decent

Cons:
-They charge you money for tea!!! They don't even ask who wants it, but still bring it out. They don't charge by the tea pot, but they charge $1 per person. Wtf???? Who does that!! So we got charged and extra $5 for tea  
-They included tip in the overall total without us knowing until we asked because the overall was quite a lot! And when we walked out one of the worker was like no tip? Uh, you guys included it in????? What the fk. Shady.. What if we didn't ask if tip was included because we can't read Chinese or understand them? So we would have given them more money than they deserved.
-They didn't give us water for like 20 minutes after we sat down.
-Fried rice was plain
-They don't know what they're talking about when you ask them stuff like my mom asked what was inside the rice noodle and all they said was vegetable. Like duh??? I know it's vegetables, but what's in it? 

Overall:
I felt like they ripped us off because we don't speak Chinese and they think we're just some Asian tourist. They should at least know what's in the food because what if someone is allergic, etc? We wanted to go to the place next door, but the wait was 50 minutes and my parents were hungry. We won't come back and I will not recommend this place to anyone
author: Vonnie T.

description: We sat down before checking the Yelp reviews and realized they had a poor health rating. We decided to stay and played it safe and offered a couple items. We ordered the pork steam buns and the shrimp dumplings. To my surprise the food was very fresh and flavorful. The shrimp was perfectly cooked and the pork buns were great as well. The only complaint is they ran out of a few of the menu items we were interested in. As of now I give them 4 stars but we'll see how the next few hours plays out haha. I'll update if anything happens .
author: Dustin B.

description: I had the spring rolls, pot stickers, shrimp dumplings and vegetarian dumplings. They give you green tea with your order.
author: Darin P.

description:
My Dim Sum was fresh, hot and delicious. 
I came here for breakfast at about 9.30 in the morning not knowing what to expect. The first thing I noticed was that I was the only non-Asian in the restaurant, to me, this was a very good sign! I was excited, it was like leaving San Fransisco and traveling to another country!  When I go out to a restaurant I want to eat authentic, regional, food, but also I go for the experience. Sometimes food is good, sometimes not so good, but I judge restaurants on the overall experience, and for this, I rate Peninsular highly.  The customers were a cross-section of society,  old and young ranging from retirees and young families to very smart business people. The fact that the restaurant probably had about 80 to 100 customers at that time of the morning says more than any review!!  The casual and comfortable way they were relaxing in the place made me think, they probably return time and time again, they must have been regulars, and would soon stop coming if the food wasn't very authentic, good and prepared and served in a way that is appropriate to the style and custom. My food was fresh, hot and delicious. When I tried to compliment the waiter as I left, and she clearly had no idea what I had said added to the charm of the whole experience.  I will return!
author: John C.

description:
Service was terrible. Food was hot but mediocre. Lacked flavoring. Never got our rice we ordered. Bathrooms were some of the worst I've seen (and Ive seen a lot). The place smelled like cigarette smoke. Not sure where that was coming from but it was noticeable and yuck. 

Gave them 1  because the hot & sour soup was decent, we were seated right away and the food didn't take too long. Sometimes you gotta suck it up when the kids are hangry. 

No fortune cookies, no "can I get you anything else". Never saw our server again after we ordered. 

But needless to write, we won't be back.
author: Mel P.

description:
My friend and I had a rather difficult time finding a nice looking restaurant or even seating for that matter so we found this place which was also packed in the weekend around 1p. After a 20 minute wait, we ordered the Peninsula Pan Fried Noodle and Mongolian Beef lunch special w/hot & sour soup.

To me, the Pan Fried Noodles is almost perfect though saltier than I would have liked and the Mongolian Beef was perfectly spiced and beef certainly did not feel tenderized for a stir fry like it usually is in other Cantonese Restaurants.

Although the Dim Sum ladies coming to you and sometimes asking you if you want their offerings can be annoying I was surprised they didn't have push carts which I actually miss seeing. They also brought someone else's order to my table by mistake twice. We also didn't order tea but they brought it over and charged us the $1 per person. Interestingly it is advertised as $0.50 but the boss explained that certain teas are $1. I guess she can say whatever she wants when adding up the bill-way to rip you off.

Though they don't rush you and we were there for about 2 hours, the boss lady has to make it a point to charge extra and try to justify why she did so in a demeaning way. They do offer free WiFi. So that's my 2 stars for them.
author: Alex H.

description: Initially I thought I'd like this place and give a decent review, but unfortunately I visited the restroom before leaving(after eating) and was appalled by the filth.  Since our visit to this place a notice has gone up on Yelp warning of the unsanitary conditions in this establishment.  So my advice would be to steer clear of this restaurant.
author: Scooter B.

description:
Mediocre dim sum, beef tastes like pee, shrimp dumplings taste nothing like shrimps. 

Chicken feet were good though.
author: Zinan X.

description:
We arrived a little bit after 3, party of 6. We had din sum and a couple of their entrees. We were immediately seated, no wait...huge plus because we were hungry! I can't remember what we ordered, we ordered off the picture menu (easier). Everything for the most part was great! 

What would have given a higher score: 
if they took drink orders, asked if we needed silverware (not everyone in our party used chopsticks), check on us to see if we needed anything else..you know the regular attention you would get. And when we ordered a second round one of the dim sum, it wasn't consistent with our initial order. Also, the second round took longer, and it seemed like it was rushed. Lastly, stay clear of the bathrooms. The women's needed major cleaning!
author: Jeannette C.

description: To be fair, the food we got was good. It isn't the food that is bad, but the service was horrible. One of the worst restaurant experiences I've had. We sat down at about 2:50pm and it took till about 4:30pm for us to get 6 dim sum dishes, we never got all the food we ordered. We saw other people sit down and leave because it was taking so long to order. We asked multiple times about when our food was coming out. We left hungry and very disappointed. I usually never write such bad yelp reviews, but this was a uniquely awful experience.
author: Danielle B.

description: Really good authentic Chinese food. There wasn't much of a wait and the tables were really clean, which can be hard to find sometimes in Chinatown. The service was really hands on and we felt well attended to. Highly suggest the chicken in lemon sauce and house fried rice. I would give this place a higher rating but the water  is from the tap and so is the water used in the green tea, so I suggest getting a soda instead. Other than that, the food was enjoyable.
author: Marialice F.

description:
My wife and I had an OK lunch here.  We were randomly strolling through Chinatown, and went to a couple of different restaurants that were rated well, only to find that they were either closed on Wednesday, or not open for whatever reason.  Finally, our hunger took control, and we were guided to the biggest sign in view...  Peninsula Seafood Restaurant.  As we walked in the place felt very authentic.  Tables were filled with Asian locals, and it appeared we were the only tourists in the joint.  We sampled one Dim Sum dish, which was pork ribs and some kind of thick noodle.  It was very good, and the meat tasted good, but there was more bone than meat (which is fine, I guess).  We then ordered Spring Rolls and Potstickters, and when they came, I enjoyed them both.  Things were kind of greasy (as if that is a bad thing), but I thought everything was tasty.  This was so for my wife, who didn't care for things too much.  Still, it was a fun experience to eat in an establishment that obviously caters to the locals, and experience things a little bit out of the box from the typical Americanized Chinese food that we are used to.  I don't know if I'd really recommend it to anyone visiting SF, but I'm sure we will be back in the hunt tonight to find something better.


[  I'd tell you a chemistry joke but I'm pretty sure I wouldn't get a reaction.  ]
author: Michael S.

description: It's actually a very great restaurant. I don't know why I can't see too many people here. I ordered steamed lobster with garlic, Taro and Chicken in Clay Pot. Both of them are awesome. You must try at least one of it :)
author: 轩飒

description: Went here wanting traditional dim sum. Was disappointed that it was not typical al la carte dim sum but rather we had to order. All the food was very good and the staff was very helpful answering any questions. Only tip: don't underestimate how much my friends can eat. But thanks for looking out for us when we ordered so much. Lol!
author: Greg P.

description:
It was my aunt's birthday and we booked three tables like we always do. I have a huge and obnoxious family but I love them to death. Alright, this review ain't about my crazy family so here we go. I gave them one star because they were patient enough to wait for the rest of my family to arrive (me because I like to fashionably late). Everything seemed to go okay until the food comes out. We ordered the set menu since we had a huge party. 

Appetizer sampler (duck, chicken, bbq pork, jelly fish) - my family complained about how horrible it was. It was ok to me, the presentation of the food was not great. 
Honey Walnut Shrimp - I was absolutely disappointed. This is the worst honey walnut shrimp ever. The mayo for the shrimp is usually a little on the sweet side but they just slathered on mayo and said "that's what the candied walnuts are for." I wanted to punch them in the face. Just rename is to Walnut shrimp, why don't cha. 
Salt and Pepper Porkchop & Sweet and Sour Pork - not bad but not to die for. 
Shrimp with Steamed Broccoli - the only dish that was decent-ish. Ish because the broccoli had no flavor but the shrimp was cooked to perfection. 
Fresh fish - Good, thank goodness it wasn't overcooked or anything. 
Roasted Squab - they ran out so my whole family had to share... ehh I've had better. 
Beef with Snow Peas - I guess order this if you really have to come here. Only dish worth re-ordering.

There might have been more dishes but I can't seem to remember. They weren't good enough to remember anyways. 

OMG and let me tell you, DO NOT LET THEM CUT YOUR BIRTHDAY CAKE. This waiter murdered our beautiful cake. He took two spoons like you would when you serve noodles at a Chinese restaurant and clawed at the cake. I was laughing at how embarrassing it looked for the damn restaurant. I would of gave you two stars but forget it. Bye.
author: Joey C.

description: Came here the second time and service is still shit. I get it you guys open early and it's hectic to get everyone their plates but if you'd show a little appreciation then customers wouldn't mind waiting a while. Came here for breakfast dim sum on MONDAY and since it was the one we know it opened early for see so we came again. It was already filled by 9AM since it was the weekend. All the seats in the outer parts were filled so we went inside where it was empty but not for long. We basically sat ourselves because did I say, service is basically shit here. Anyways sat down for two minutes and the waiter(this rude one I'm about to talk about) gave us our tea. Five minutes later he gives us the sheet to decide what dim sum we want to order and keep in mind the menu does not have pictures which is so inconvenient. Ordered about 8-10 plates(they're tiny btw) for total of three people. When I have him the paper, he swung the paper so quick on the table and came down frustrated saying "Are you sure you wanna order that much, not even eight people order this much. Cuz when we bring the food you can't say you don't want it." Exactly what he freaking said in Chinese. So I look over it again and I know the dishes are small so of course I kept what I want. Like I don't need your opinion or your two cents like you can tell he didn't want to be there working. Mister if you don't wanna work then don't, don't give me fucking attitude you little shit. Anyways I hate this place and most definitely not going to come back unless this place improves.
author: Lisa W.

description: If you're in the neighborhood this is a great place to grab dim sum in the morning. A favor for the locals. The price is reasonable and I like their rice porridge,  shrimp dumplings and pork dumpling.
author: LL Y.

description: As a preface, I've probably had Peking duck over 100 times in my life, countless 11 course dinners for birthdays, weddings, regular dinners out with my boyfriend.   This was by FAR the best duck I've had.  The skin is perfectly crisp, not as fatty but extremely succulent and the flavours.   I definitely recommend anyone going to San Fran try this restaurant in China town.
author: Jen K.

description: We stumbled into this in search of dim sum and were not disappointed.  Out of buns, so we stretched our pedestrian dim sum taste buds and loved dumplings and pot stickers and shrimp rolls.  The best dish was the Chinese broccoli that was served as we sat and perused the menu. Fresh, crisp and delicious.  Slow service was appreciated as we savored each bite and eavesdropping on the tables around us.
author: Lynne O.

description: VERY BAD AND RUDE SERVICE CREW. They ignore our dimsum order and said that they don't have it anymore. And speaking in there dialect or pretend that they did not get the order since who have to order the dimsum in check what you like.
author: Barnard B.

description:
A couple of must trys in this restaurant:
Black pepper beef short ribs
Preserved egg and pork porridge
Mushroom with pork dumpling
author: Michelle L.

description:
On Saturday, I was invited to a wedding. I took forever for me to sit and knowing that I want a chair. We arrived at the restaurant that we are told too. And it took forever until the food came and then waiters started to push in. 

First appetizer was some raw meats with vegetables and so on. 

I would say the food was extremely amazing. And I never been into this restaurant.
The soda was extremely off its brand. Its says 7up it taste it been sitting in the sun. 

Food:4.5/5
Drink:2/5
Décor: 2/5
Service: 5/5
author: Nq V.

description:
Overall, I'd give this place a solid 3 stars. Their food is probably a little better than that, but their service brings back even to 3 stars. I will say that when we came at around 12pm on a Sunday, there was a huge crowd waiting. The line definitely moves, but be ready for a wait. All in all, nothing fancy, nothing terrible. Just a run of the mill 3 star dim sum place in the Bay Area.

QUALITY
Nothing to rail on, but certainly nothing to write home about. I'd say it's right about middle of the road: your average dim sum place with a few dishes hitting a little below the line. I didn't try any of their regular dishes, so I won't say anything about those. 

SERVICE
I'd say coming to Peninsula will leave you with a fairly authentic Chinese dining experience. Really loud servers running around crowded tables of even louder patrons. They didn't have the dim sum pushcarts around, which I attribute to the relatively cramped seating arrangements they have, so you have to order most of your dim sum items from the menu. Unfortunately, it takes quite a long time for them to bring the food out. My girlfriend had to flag someone down twice to make sure they didn't forget our food. They do have attendants walking around with platters with some of the more popular dim sum items though, so you won't have to wait there.

FINAL TAKE
It's alright dim sum. Nothing to write home about to the mother land (if you're from there). There are probably better places to try in the Bay.
author: Zi-on C.

description: Ok I am going to give it to you all straight... the physical venue is awful!  The back half of the restaurant smells like mildew... but the front half is "ok" ... but overlook all that because when I tell you this was the BEST!!!! Chinese food I have ever had in my life.  I would gladly go back again for the food... but yea this location needs a new venue.  Also, I don't think the name is accurate so just follow the address. OK this is family style and all three of us had very different taste. We had the mayonnaise shrimp, dim sum, tofu, fried rice, stuff mushrooms, and some other stuff. Amazing food, horrible location!  But go here cause every good dinning experience needs a crazy story to go with it loll.
author: Kitty B.

description: We were rushed in and fed.  I have no clue what I ate,  people were just walking around with trays hollering out in Chinese.  The restaurant was noisy with locals, and a local shop owner recommended it,  which is why we choose it.  What we ate was good,  but I wish we knew more what was going on. Following our meal,  I logged on to place a review and saw the poor food warning thing because they were in the bottom 5%of food inspections in the city.
author: Kristy R.

description: I came here with a bunch of friends and they could accommodate the 10 of us without a reservation.  That was nice.  However, I wasn't a big fan of the food.  It wasn't bad, but to me, it wasn't good either.
author: Brent T.

description: Average dim sum. Chive shrimp dumpling was the best item we had. Other dumplings too mushy for my taste. Quick service and I did appreciate the vegetarian options and easy to use menu.
author: Lauren M.

description:
Sunday @ 2PM, Dim Sum w/ the extended family. No line. Busy but got seated right away with the roaming Dim Sum pushing ladies appearing seconds after we filled the seats. 

Interestingly, Great Eastern Restaurant a couple of doors down had a line down the block. I woulda thunk by now the magic of the Obama visit almost a year ago would have worn off. Smart marketing move of having a big poster board with pictures, and proud proclamation that indeed Obama got take out  there.

Back to Peninsula, its the usual Dim Sum fare, we ordered some menu dishes as well.  Properly & nicely prepared, we enjoyed the meal.
author: Matsuo U.

description: Do not recommend. Dim sum has no flavor and the shrimp roll tastes like tap water. Everything was super bland, and even the sesame ball was cold. The only thing that was good here was the tea.
author: David S.

description: The only good on this restaurant is the Coke in Can $1.50.... Horrible service + Horrible Food = 20% automatic gratuity... SMFH. Don't eat here.
author: Russ R.

description:
Went back again after a few months. The food is now tasteless! We talked to the manager about it and she said there's a no salt healthy fad going on so they don't put salt any more. She even suggested adding soy sauce. Either way adding salt or soy sauce wouldn't help. There is no taste on anything. 

Yum char service is poor too. It took us 20 mins to finally have someone with food to offer. Terrible wouldn't go back again.
author: Alliv S.

description: Ordered a whole Peking duck.  Not only the skin was super soft and nearly cold to the touch, it was missing some pieces (notably missing a wing and a thigh).  Reported to a waiter and waitress and both claim that's a whole duck.  I've had much more authentic Peking duck several times and I know this wasn't right.  Still got charged for a whole duck afterwards and we were not even informed that tea ended up being a $10 surcharge on my bill for 1 kettle + 1 refill.  Not a recommended place for dim sum either because the dumplings we ordered were apparently reheated and does not taste fresh at all.  I'd rather go to New Asia Restaurant or Yummy Yummy, both on Pacific Ave between Stockton and Grant, to eat similar dishes next time.
author: David N.

description:
Unsure of the many choices in restaurants in Chinatown. We decided to stay at this one because we were famished from a long day in Chinatown and it was cleaner than the previous restaurants we've checked out. 

We ordered too much food! First time ordering dim sum and got double of everything. Server failed to mention to me how many in each order. Good looking out guy!

Ordered the dim sum usuals: shrimp dumpling and shumai. I loved the shrimp dumpling. Soft, moist, and full of flavor. 

Honey Walnut Shrimp was one of the best I have tasted. Not too sweet. It came with lots of shrimp as well. 

Chicken Bak Choy was good. The only thing I loved were the big pieces of bak choy. Tasted fresh!

Fried rice was light in color and flavor. I actually liked it. It was not heavy and oily like others I have tasted. 

Expensive lunch with lots of takeout! Sad thing is, I've never had really great Chinese food ever so I enjoyed it. Food trumps service for sure!

My boyfriend and I got serviced the most in that restaurant. I felt bad for the others that waited a long time to order anything. I felt like I was ignored when I asked for a drink. Funny thing is, when my boyfriend ordered (he's asian, maybe they thought he was local? Idk?) he got it right away. Most tables in the dining room were dirty and not bussed. There were only 4 tables of diners while we were there and their service sucked. Is this typical in Chinatown? A table even walked out. Yikes.
author: Jacqueline G.

description: Fast service. We were seated in 4 minutes, and a dim sum waitress approached us literally seconds later. The food was good, the price reasonable. Also, free wifi. I have no complaints.
author: Connie C.

description: solid dim sum without the massive lines next door at great eastern.  Give it a whirl
author: Matt S.

description:
Dinner (dim sum is only for lunch, of course), was surprisingly satisfying. I am an ABC from an LA suburb with what must be 600+ delicious Chinese restaurants, and this probably could fit in with them if only for the delicious BEIJING DUCK. I've had a lot of Beijing duck, one of my favorite dishes, and this was the best one I've ever had! My immigrant parents also agreed. It's so juicy and has a rich and perfect amount of fat under crispy skin. You have to take the bone off with a little difficulty because of the perfect plumpness, but it is so worth it when you jam it between fluffy buns with sweet sauce and leeks that add the perfect touch of freshness and texture for contrast. The Beijing duck is definitely FIVE STARS.

The rest of the food is also good and authentic. The soup is tasty. This is definitely better than the super expensive and touristy Great Eastern restaurant next door! Peninsula serves mostly local Chinese among other customers. Nice service; they help change plates often.
author: Gloria C.

description:
I ate here over a year ago and gave it a 5-star review and expected to have the same good food and okay service but what a huge let down. We picked Peninsula since they open earlier in the morning for dim sum than Great Eastern (3 doors down). We arrived around 8:30am and were surprised that it was almost packed with local senior citizens, many of them sitting by themselves at tables for 4 people.

The service was non-existent this time around. We were pointed to sit at a round table for 6 (we were a party of 2). The waiter barely looked at us and never made eye contact. He didn't even say a word during our entire meal. We had to wait and wait to flag him down to get the bill at the end of the meal.

This time, the dim sum was not very tasty. The steamed beef balls were tough and the chicken feet was bland. We ordered several dishes of dim sum, none were memorable. During our meal, we saw a couple of single senior citizens change their tables without asking the waiter for permission. Weird! The atmosphere was depressing and the bad food and bad service made this a 1-star dining experience.  I will NOT be returning!
author: Zoey W.

description:
So we were in Chinatown looking for dim sum, but we failed to consider that all the good, cheap, dim sum places were bakeries and would be closing by dinnertime. By the time we arrived at the place we intended to get food from (which was closed), we were hungry and tired, so decided to just eat at the first half-decent-looking place we saw that had dim sum, which turned out to be here. 

Well, yelp was right on the money: 3 stars indeed. It looked good from the start, in that we were the only non-Asian-looking people sitting down for dinner, which is generally a good sign, as is a waiter asking us what we wanted almost immediately. Less of a good sign was the fact that when we had decided, they explained (in broken English, of course, but that's expected) that they were out of like a third of the dim sum on the menu, even though it was specifically a dinner menu and it was only like 6:30 - though, he later came back and told us that actually the item we'd tried to order that he said was out, actually *wasn't* out and did we want to order it? 

Good thing we did, too, as that item (the beef rice noodle roll) was the highlight of the dinner: it was extremely good. The scallops with spicy garlic sauce was also extremely good (I'd say even given its price - scallops are expensive, and they do give you a decent number of them); the mongolian beef, I've had better, but it wasn't bad. The pork spare ribs, on the other hand, were disgusting: they were almost entirely bone and gristle (maybe this is how authentic Chinese food lovers like it? I can't imagine.) We took one bite, and threw the rest away (actually, we tried to leave it on the table, but they wouldn't let us. Hilariously, they really thought we wanted it to go, and when we left the togo box on the table, they chased us out with it, so we just had to leave it on a trash can outside.) And the third dim sum item we ordered never showed up: apparently they ran out of that one, and didn't think to tell us until we asked about it as we were ready to leave. They asked if we wanted something else instead, but at that point we were perfectly happy to leave. At least they didn't still charge us for the item, as I've seen happen sometimes.

So basically, exactly what you would expect from a place that has 3 stars on yelp: some food good, some food not so good, some aspects of service good, some aspects of service not so good. I wouldn't be angered if a friend wanted to go here again, but I might encourage the thought of going somewhere else instead.

edit: I will mention, their hot sauce on the table was super tasty too. No idea if they make it themselves, or just get it from a package, but if the latter, whoever they get it from makes good hot sauce.
author: Adam F.

description: Seated right away, which was good. Food was decent. Bathrooms were disgusting. The service was horrible! Server would not split our check. When we suggested, he got mad. Did not offer to get refills on drinks or asked if we needed anything else.
author: Kylie C.

description: Terrible food, terrible service. Wait 5' in the front desk and no one come to ask while the waiter( tall guy) is using his phone. When we was seated, and done with my menu, 3 waiters walked by us and pretended that the didnt see anything, 1 waiter stood next to my table and chatted with the other customer then gone. Wtf??? Their uniforms look like haven't been washed for couple months. The floor is dirty and food is unflavored. My gf found a piece of glasses in her food. Luckily it didnt cut her. I wonder what will happen if she swallow it???
author: Tyler D.

description:
Food- I came for the dim sum and the dim sum was good. The flavors are strong. But that's good with me. 

Service- I came off peak hours so I didn't wait at all. I also went alone. The ladies don't push the food and shows you what they have. 

Atmosphere- Pretty nice. Can't beat being surrounded by larger Asian families speaking Chinese (not sure what dialect). 

That being said this is for someone who isn't afraid to go to a restaurant that doesn't speak much English.
author: Tiffani N.

description:
MSG Headache - Ow!

That said this place serves supper yummy dim sum ALL DAY (ask for menu). Service is surprisingly friendly and helpful - anything we asked for came with a 'right away' and it really did.

Prices are great. Just be sure to double check your dim sum order sheet. I thought ours looked pre-marked and we wound up with much more than we ordered (see photo link above) Maybe they thought we were clueless tourists?

Still, we'd go back.
author: Steven B.

description:
Famished is a word that I rarely use, but I was feeling somewhat that on this particular day as a medical appointment and a series of errands left my stomach growling to be fed.  Having to fast for 12 hours prior to the appointment didn't help either as my tank was nearing zero.

Not having experienced much dining out in the Chinatown area and too lazy to reach for my phone and ask Yelp for help, I came upon this restaurant.  My memory usually serves me well, and I recalled having read some decent reviews about this place when they opened.

I was greeted as soon as I walked in and a table for two was quickly cleaned and reset for me by a waiter.  Asked by the gentleman who seated me whether I was interested in their regular lunch menu or dim sum menu I chose the latter not having that for several weeks.

The dim sum menu came in the form of two check off lists and a pencil.  I truly enjoy this method of ordering over the old fashioned push cart method.  I selected several choices and handed the list back to the gentleman when he came by to ask whether I had completed my order.  I'm assuming the man that helped me is either a manager or even a part owner of the restaurant as I noticed him make a gesture to a waiter who immediately brought me a hot pot of tea.

The man returned once again to inform me that the dim sum would be steamed to order so I should expect a bit of the wait.  That was fine with me as the hot tea had helped to numb my belly.

Once the food began to arrive they came out in two separate waves.  That was perfect for it gave me the chance to eliminate some of the dishes quicker to make room for others.  

The Shrimp Dumpling (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/8zVnG-g4dRNQtheaTv6t1Q#hh0YZIRmSb5q4N8u1pKptQ) was loaded with firm chunks of shrimp, but I detected MSG and lots of it.  The Pork & Mushroom Dumplings (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/8zVnG-g4dRNQtheaTv6t1Q#0P9T525tP6KWZOyPCeQx0g) were much better.  The amount of shrimp was the showcase in these bites much more than the pork or the mushroom.  Better yet that I couldn't detect MSG in these.  The Bean Curd Sheet with Oyster Sauce (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/8zVnG-g4dRNQtheaTv6t1Q#Aj2uEe9TVMP_Q8KVqEq-Hg) turned out to be my favorite generously stuffed with ground pork, more shrimp and vegetables (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/8zVnG-g4dRNQtheaTv6t1Q#ZZIa1-WECQfuXXK-i90IMA).  For some reason the kitchen was too lazy to reheat the Potstickers (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/8zVnG-g4dRNQtheaTv6t1Q#tx6seZ8N-PapcV5whvi0Fw) obviously pre-cooked and served cold and chewy; otherwise, round one was a hit.

Round two turned out to be a mix.  The steamed Mushroom & Chicken Bun had very little chicken and mushroom (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/8zVnG-g4dRNQtheaTv6t1Q#RijC6cOyniiGuYeNN-1oYA) which might have been a blessing for it was extremely dry.  I much preferred having just the steamed bun portion on its own.  The Sesame Puffs (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/8zVnG-g4dRNQtheaTv6t1Q#NdfbT7r4G02MYKUlTChZ6A), at the least, were served hot from the fryer.  I loved those especially with its generous pocket of red bean paste inside.

When the man returned to see how I was doing I think he was shocked that I had eaten almost everything brought out to me.  I asked for a small box for my two sesame puffs and one steamed bun and asked the waiter to discard the potstickers.

Some hits and some misses but very good service made for a rather enjoyable lunch.  At least my stomach was happy.
author: Wilhelm Y.

description: We were walking around chinatown looking for dim sum and saw this place. I ordered shrimp dumplings, pot stickers, custard buns, chow fun, walnut shrimp and shrimp noodle. I loved all the flavors. The place itself was average as far as seating, cleanliness, atmosphere, but I was most interested in the taste of the food, so I was a happy camper.
author: Grace F.

description:
Finally discovered an awesome find in Chinatown! As a Chinatown local, this place is very reasonably priced for the great quality of food you can find at other higher end restaurants.

I had....

-Geoduck steamed with garlic sauce, called "guai fay pong" (the vermicelli was nestled inside the shell, so it sopped up all the sauce and geoduck juices...mmm)
-Clams with garlic black bean sauce (pretty standard)
-Pan fried carp with ginger and scallion sauce (decided to try this instead of the typical steamed version; really tender fish and the sauce seemed to make the fish sweeter; good call! *pat on the back...)
-Sauteed pea shoots with garlic (...again...pretty standard...can't really mess this one up either; it was good)
-Salt and pepper fried crab (finger-licking-tasty! loved the little bits of leftover cracklings to mix into my rice...yes, like a fatty.)
-Mango pudding dessert (prettty mango-ey but I kinda wish they had chunks of mangoes in there as well...still good!)

Overall experience was quite good. Friendly staff; aside from refilling water back into my tea kettle, they even poured tea into my cup! (*two-fingered tap-tap)
Besides where the heck in Chinatown are you gonna find a full service menu of dim sum all day long?!!!....yeah...thought so.
author: Connie L.

description: Went today for dim sum lunch. Delicious food and great service! Everything was excellent.
author: Matt T.

description: You will regret your decision to eat here. I had the worst chinese food experience here.
author: Thomas L.

description: Another place I discovered because of my parents.  They have good set menus for great prices.  I liked the Seafood Clay Pot and the Clams in black bean sauce.  The Clams were big and juicy and the plate had a good amount of them.  The Seafood clay pot was delish and full of veggies, scallops, squid, etc.  Would definitely come back to try some other dishes.  Or the dim sum!
author: Elena N.

description:
You know you're in the right place when you walk into a Chinese restaurant that is packed with local Chinese people.  I grew up in Chinatown so I'm pretty choosy when it comes to picking a Chinese restaurant.  I avoid those that are tailored to tourists since they are generally much more expensive and quality is often mediocre at best.  I also avoid those that are visited by big-name politicians since those are often the biggest rip off.  

While the service you get at Peninsula is dismal at best, the food and value is really good.  You cannot find a better value dim sum restaurant for the price in SF Chinatown.  When you are there, you can be adventurous and try out some of the more exotic dishes like chicken feet (Phoenix Claws is the fancy name we use), pig's blood and pork skin (coagulated pig blood), and pig's intestines.  Or you can stick to the more traditional dim sum like Har Gow (shrimp dumpling), Siu Mai (pork dumpling), Cha Siu Bau (BBQ pork buns), and my personal favorite, Beef Cheung Fun (fat rice noodles with beef).  One dessert that this place makes that is really good is the Malay Sponge Cake.  It's called Ma Lai Go if you want to ask for it.

I brought a group of 12 people for dim sum and we walked out spending only $75 including tips and there were still a lot of leftover dim sum.  So, you will enjoy some good authentic dim sum at this place without breaking your bank.

When you are there, try some authentic Chinese tea also.  The dark tea (Po Lay) really helps with digestion and washing down the grease from the food.  Just ask for "Po Lay Cha" when the waiter comes around.  If you prefer a less bitter tea, try the "Sau Mei Cha".  It's not as strong as Po Lay and do help with digestion as well.  Now you're ready to eat like a local!
author: Jon L.

description: My friends and I (group of 4) were seated immediately but were ignored for half an hr afterwards. After entrapping the waiter to take our order (I dropped the menu, waited for him to pick it up and then pounced with my order), we had to wait half another half an hr until the first dim sum dish came out. An hr and a half later, our other dishes came out and the hostess said that our shanghai dumplings took a long time to cook. DO NOT BLAME THE SHANGHAI DUMPLINGS. The couple next to us sat down and left after half an hr because they never received their food and only had tea served to them. Bless their souls, they left a couple of dollars on the table for the free tea. At one point, the child in another group stared crying because he was so hungry. We left hungrier than when we sat down since it took over an hr. This review is delayed (we went to the restaurant last Saturday) just like the service.
author: Jerry W.

description: Seriously underrated dim dum! Everything we ordered was fresh and not too greasy. The steam short ribs has real orange zest to it! Bitter melon in the chang fen. Yummy. Efficient service. Much impressed.
author: Angel A.

description:
Favorite dim sum!! Especially since they have many options all day! 

Every time my girlfriend and I visit the city we make a point to come to P&R Seafood. Whatever time of day we manage to stagger through the door, we are always met with kind, efficient service and a high quality dish or two. 

I strongly recommend finding your way to this restaurant early enough to enjoy the full dim sum menu. Granted, if that doesn't workout anything fish and anything duck will not disappoint. Happy eating!
author: Sarah H.

description:
My family came here last night around 8:30 l and I would have to disagree with the previous reviews on the service because the waiters were extremely nice and warm welcoming, especially this one guy. I wish I got his name, but the service was by far the best I've gotten in a Chinatown. 

Menu for the night: 
Honey Walnut Prawns (absolutely my favorite dish.. you can never go wrong)
Fried rice (a little bit plain, but at least they didn't drench it with soy sauce) 
Pan fried noodle (I only like the crispy noodles) 

It's a typical Chinese restaurant, yet I would still come back for the service and the food wasn't too greasy either.
author: Lisa T.

description:
The food is " SUCK " And the services is ok. I went there Sunday, 11/25/12.
1st. when you go inside; make fell like a boss, I server the tea to my wife, I seat down, when server pork portage, she use the server plate to push my tea few down to my pant, and she keep said; sorry. then I said; it's ok.that not problem.
later they server the chonfun (  ) is overnight which is is stink, and spare rid (  ) there is some matel in in the plate, and the pot sticker teasty weird. 
The services is ok, but the food is " SUCK "
so I am not going to eat there again.
author: Jackson L.

description:
Parking: idk street or garage. Pick the lesser of two evils 

Cheap for nor cal dim sum, but dirty! The person didn't really clean the table. They usually change the cloth and everything but instead they just changed the paper mats that lined throughout the outside of the table. There was still food stuck from previous customers underneath the glass lazy susan. 

The food wasn't amazing nor was it bad. The clay pot rice was a rip off! 8 bucks and there was a lack of toppings!! not worth it.
author: Willis W.

description: Seriously the worst chinese food i have ever had. And some awful service to match. They took forever to bring out everything. Egg rolls were frozen in the middle. Crab was deep fried like a damn corn dog. We ordered a 1/4 duck and they literally gave us all spine and scrappy tid bits. The honey and walnut shrimp was slathered in mayo. MAYO?!? Whyy? Im so confused. I literally feel i'm either on drugs or on a reality tv show. This place is terrible. Run.
author: David B.

description:
Locates right in the heart of the San Francisco China Town, this is an old, sorry to say, and traditional Cantonese style restaurant. We came in here two days before Chinese New Year, when the China Town was packed with visitors all around. We decided to go with the one restaurant with the most senior Chinese patrons, which could indicated the foods were good.

We got the number 42 after we registered at the front desk. Surprisingly, we only waited about 15 minutes and got our table. When we walked in, we found out there were three rooms with maybe more than 70 tables inside. What a view!

They served quite authentic Dim Sum with servants carrying different dishes all over the tables. The tastes were quite OK, and costs were reasonable. 

The down side, the restaurant was a bit old, and could use a facelift. Service could be improved, but maybe because it's Chinese New Year's weekend. Still recommend.
author: Eric H.

description:
My brother and I went on a trip to San Francisco a few weeks back when I was in town and we decided to drive into the city to get some duck. Its been many years since I've eaten in Chinatown so I wasn't very familiar with the restaurants. We decided to try Peninsula since there wasn't a line and we were hungry. The interior is what you would expect with many Chinese restaurants. The wait staff was very attentive and gave excellent suggestions for our meal.

My brother and I started with the Peking duck which was my favorite part of the meal. The meat was cooked perfectly with a nice crispy skin. We then ordered Pork fried rice, broccoli with oyster sauce, garlic pork chops and sweet and sour pork. Each dish was prepared very well. One thing I like about this restaurant is that they serve family style (which is something I didn't expect). The portions were huge and my brother and I basically took home a lot of food.

Overall, a really good experience...I'll have to come back and try the dim sum when I'm back up here.
author: Jim A.

description: This place is very interesting. Ordered duck app which only had spine and neck pieces. We ordered the shrimp and walnuts in a honey glaze, it was covered in MAYO, which was hot...so confused. I ordered the shrimp egg foo young which was alright. Hard to mess that up. After waiting for our good for an hour we realized we should have just waited in line at a better place than just choose a restaurant because we were hungry.
author: Amanda M.

description:
Their dim sum is amazing! It doesn't get pushed around on a cart until it gets soggy and cold like most places. They bring it fresh from the kitchen once you order it. You can also get your parking validated which is great because parking in Chinatown is a pain.

I would definitely recommend the steamed shrimp dumplings and the sticky rice wrapped in a lotus leaf.
author: Ray W.

description:
Peninsula Seafood has a grand opening sign in front. the namesm,  Peninsula and P & R,  both show up on the marquee. previous name was Pearl City.  there was a bunch of people leaving when we entered 9:30ish. seems they came from a tour bus.

dim sum review only:
dim sum pricing: (s)2.2 (m)2.80 (L)3.20 tea@person (1)

eats:
-black bean sparerib(s)
kind of chewy,  big boned, not much taste beyond grease.
-beef ball(s)
dry firm meat, not soft. no corn starch used? 
-shrimp cheung(l)
mostly crunchy, tasteless shrimps. some "grass" taste.
"skin" firm, not silky soft
-siu mai (4./m)
no shrimp inside, dry tasting, meat texture firm, not soft
-fun  gow (4/m)
pretty big sized. lots of veggies, stuff inside. fell apart easily

foodnotes:
-early in the morn, no hostess,  greeted by managers/waiters who told you where to sit.
-when door is open, cold air made eating uncomfy.
-cheap eats, not tasty though. relatively good service.(still early)

chinese lessons           mandarin
siu mai                            shao1 mai4
author: Victor G.

description:
We arrived at 11 A.M. and had to wait awhile for a table, even though plenty of empty tables were available.  A dim sum menu is provided so that diners can mark their selections and order them right away.  Some items are also brought from table to table, so you can select something you did not see on the menu.  Most diners seemed to be ordering large plates of noodles instead of dim sum.  The price per order was reasonable at $3-4.  
However, I had to deduct a star for the restrooms.  Any other restaurant would have closed for repairs and cleaning with a restroom in such bad repair.  Cardboard on the floor, the floor drain open, water splashing from G*d-knows-where.
author: Cathy T.

description: When all the nearby restaurants are booked or too crowded and you are hungry, this is your only option. To start, the concept of waiting dies not exist. Just stand there and hike they call your name and don't let anyone cut in front of you. Food is average like all the other reviewers stated. Slow service.
author: DJ N.

description: Visited this resturant during Superbowl. The food was delicious and the staff was wonderful. I highly recommended this place when I'm Chinatown.
author: Keith W.

description:
After coming here I can see why it averaged 3 stars.  The food here is really good and tasty; you only saw Chinese people here, which is a really good sign.  However, the service here is ridiculously slow.  Like snail's pace slow.  I could ave sent mail Priority Mail faster than this.  WE came here for dim sum, and unlike other dim sum places where they push the carts around, the servers here actually come around with the dishes on trays.  not very efficient.  And to add to that, they put us in the way back corner, so we hardly saw anyone pass by.   

They have you order what you want with a list also, but we still didn't see our food after that.  We had to tell the server that if they can't serve us what we ordered, we'll just leave and go elsewhere.  There was one server who was very nice and tried her best to accommodate to us, but the rest were not helpful at all.  They were very good about water and tea refills though (I think it's because the bussers handle this job). 

We ordered shu mai, which tasted pretty good, and hacao, which was REALLY good (impressive for a restaurant of this caliber).  We also ordered these rice rolls with shrimps, which were very tasty, and bok choi, which was also good.  The stuffed mushrooms were ok, the egg rolls were yummy, and there was this one item I thought was an egg roll that tasted pretty gross.  It looked like a fuzzy egg roll, but instead of meat in it, it had taro or something.  I had asked the server if it was egg roll and like many Chinese who can't understand English, she nodded yes anyway.  No...that was NOT an egg roll.  Far from it!  I didn't like it at all.  This was a day I wish I spoke Mandarin.   

To add to that, they had a Yelp check-in offer for a free egg roll that was not even honored.  No one knew about it or couldn't speak English, and it seemed like even the manager didn't even know what was up.  Dudes, if you won't honor the damn check-in offer, don't even offer it.  It was only an egg roll, but it was the principle behind it all that bothered us.  

I guess like most Chinese restaurants, don't expect great service.  Focus on the food and you're good!
author: Diane V.

description: Food is good and authentic. I noticed it's mostly local people there. I am a vegetarian and enjoyed the vegetable dumplings a lot and was told that the meat quality in some dumplings were not that good. The taro buns are absolutely delicious.
author: C W.

description: The line was too long at the restaurant we intended to go, so we walked into this one randomly. Turned out to be a big mistake. Very poor service and not clean. The food is mediocre at the best.  Will never come back again.
author: Travis Z.

description:
Not a place I will be returning to

Cons:
-waitress was inattentive and pretty sure she forgot to place our order as we waited over 30 minutes for any food to appear.  In addition, we never saw her again after she took our order 
-the sweet and sour chicken was fairly inedible.  very little meat with thick and overly fried batter.   I have had way better elsewhere...

Pros:
-once we notified the manager of our situation and the fact that we were starving, she was very proactive in getting our food out as quickly as possible.
author: Viv J.

description: If possible, I would give 0 stars! Let's just say that their bathrooms should have been an indicator to stay away from here.... Dirty bathrooms and mediocre Chinese food.  Sure enough I came down with food poisoning later that night :(
author: Debbie N.

description:
3.5 stars - had I written a review after our first dim sum experience, it would have been 4 stars but we returned for dinner and another round of dim sum - it averages to a 3.5.

Dim sums we had on the 2 visits:
spareribs - $2.20 - flavorful and tender
chicken feet - $2.20 - tasty
beef ball - $2.20 - pretty good
shrimp dumpling - $2.80 - it's ok
chiu chao dumpling - $2.80 - good, has all the right ingredients
tripe w/ ginger and green onion - $2.80 - tasty
bean curd rolls - $2.80 - tasty, it's was packed w/ meat
pork dumpling - $2.80 - ok
beef rice noodle roll - $3.20 - pretty good

For dinner, we had:
fish head - it must have a HUGE fish, there were plenty meat.  it was so good...
pea shoots w/ garlic - pretty good
eight precious w/ tofu - ok
broccoli beef pan fried noodles - ok

They have clay pot rice so we'll be back to try that.
author: Gloria H.

description:
6 GIANT steamed oysters in black bean sauce for only $6.95, everyday!!  

This place has some great seafood dishes, right now its their grand opening so they have a $12.99 lobster and noodle special, but their other dishes like giant surf clam and the oysters are great choices here.  If you are up for it, try the salt and pepper fish heads.  They are perfectly crispy on the outside while still fatty and juicy on the inside.  

It's a pretty large sized family restaurant with many seafood options, take advantage of their grand opening specials but if not get the giant oysters for about $1 a piece, just about everyone was getting them here.  I know in Chicago, those suckers cost at least $3 a pop.  

We had 5 seafood dishes (2 lobsters, 1 giant surf clams), a satay beef and some veggie dishes, only $90 after taxes.  Not bad at all.
author: Kevin W.

description:
This place changed management/ownership only a few weeks ago. I tried dim sum here on a Saturday morning. There was no wait and wasn't particularly crowded though it definitely had a decent number of people.

The quality of the dim sum was definitely on the higher end of Chinatown. Here's a list of the dishes you can't go wrong with here:

Gai Bao - chicken bun
Har Gow - shrimp dumpling
Shumai - pork dumpling
Pai Guck - steamed spare ribs
Jean Dui - sesame seed dumplings with bean paste

For two people, it came out to be about $16 total. It's a solid choice for dim sum without fighting the crowds.
author: Victor W.

description:
Stopped by here for a late dinner last night after visiting the Org nearby. Though there are a billion restaurants in Chinatown, this was one of the only ones we found open at 9:20PM- they actually close at 9:30 but didn't mind us coming in and were helpful throughout our visit, even though we didn't leave until just after 10. They were moving furniture around and cleaning up for the last few minutes of our visit, which we did not mind.

As we were seated, got a hot pot of tea- green, I think it was. Good thing we did, too, because we were seated right under an AC vent and I was freezing the entire time and the tea really warmed me up. 
Let BF do all the ordering because the menu overwhelmed me a bit. We ended up getting the lemon chicken (which arrived a la carte, no rice), one of the chow mein dishes (sadly can't remember which- I think seafood), and the bbq pork egg foo young.
All the dishes were awesome. Can't pick a favorite because they were all good in different ways that somehow complemented one another.

The lemon chicken came out first, an a la carte portion that didn't seem as large as the price may have indicated but then again I'm used to lunch prices. The sauce was bad ass though- lemony and lightly sweet, almost like honey. I've never tasted a sauce this good. Felt that the chickne was a little too crispy/crunchy though, and could have been more moist. But like I said, the sauce? Phenom.
Chow Mein was a huge portion, lots of green onion with scallops, squid, and shrimp throughout. Noodles thick and ropy, and chewy- very fresh and delicious. Sauce was subtle and really made the dish. Would order again. In fact, this dish makes me more inclined to order chow mein elsewhere in the future, now that I've tasted a really good version of it.
Lastly, the egg foo young. When we were last in Houston, I had an awesome egg foo young. That one almost doesn't even compare to this one. It was huge, for starters, and somehow really delicate. The egg and the pork really complemented one another, both savory but the egg plainer to let the pork itself shine. The sauce and green onions really brought the egg and pork together, too. Highly recommend this dish, would order again.

Service was fine. Nothing to write home about, nothing to complain about. Multiple servers checked on us, which was really nice and surprising.
