Side note: if you go to dine in, check in with your Yelp app for a free egg roll! Didn't think to check in until we were leaving and they were already technically closed, so I saved mine to redeem another time.
author: Stefany V.

description: My mom and I came here for dim sum and had a pleasant experience. My boyfriend told me that if you want to eat at a good restaurant, look inside, because you know it's good if you see people eating in the restaurant, which is exactly what we did today. We were seated immediately and they had servers at every table serving dim sum. All of them spoke Cantonese, but once they saw our forks, they explained what everything was in English lol. The service was prompt, and one of the waitresses saw that my mom barely ate the chicken feet, so she brought my mom the warm chicken feet instead. Great service! Our total was less than $20 for dim sum, which is how it should be!
author: Joyce E.

description:
Good food, but generic spotty service like any other Chinese seafood place. I think we did get better service because we were speaking Cantonese with the waiter.

The menu is a bit generic for dinner -- with that I was tempted to give it a 3 stars. Nothing on it screams authentic Chinese, but of course, a lot of American Chinese dishes do borrow from the originals.

We had the peking duck, the fried young chicken, Szechuan spicy shrimp, and broccoli/napa cabbage with crab. I didn't particularly like the broccoli dish but the other dishes were very good. The shrimp was pretty spicy and was very flavourful. The peking duck? Crispy goodness, with enough meat to pack home and still tasted great after reheating. The fried chicken was very tender as well.

Overall, they do some good Chinese food here, much to my surprise (I've lost faith in most Chinatown restaurants). The price is not that cheap coz it's in Chinatown after all. Worth a visit if you're in the vicinity.
author: Alice C.

description:
Chinese urban family restaurant on Jackson above Jackson Square. This is a locals spot for lunch populated by neighborhood color.

Here is my review on Yelp's 5-point scale of 1-5.

price/quality #4
physical site #3
coffee #na (tea is 4)
food #3
wine  #0   
service  #4
host #3. 

Why do I really eat here? It's endorsed by neighborhood. But I do not know all the spots.
author: Yeksol D.

description: Avoid this place!!! I would give them zero stars if I could!! First, the service is terrible. They act like they don't even care if they have customers or not. I waited for so long and they gave someone else a table that came in way later than me. Horrible management. Second, the food wasn't that good. I feel like it was flavorless. Lastly, the restrooms and the whole restaurant was so dirty!! I was worried if I would get food poisoning or not. Save time and money on this place and go somewhere else.
author: Rachel W.

description:
Worst service ever. 

Waiters and waitresses pretend they don't see you when you try to make eye contact and/or wave at them. 

The dim sum was decent at best, and would take a good 25-30 min before they bring it to your table. 

Do not go to this place unless you've exhausted all of your dim sum options.
author: Kenneth C.

description: I haven't eaten the food but while we are waiting for the service ( for 20 minutes so far ) I decided to write a comment , if you are in a hurry or expect nice service, even average , don't come eat here. I came here because I didn't want to wait for the table in other Restaurants nearby. There is a reason why there is no line for this place!!!!!
author: Johnny Z.

description:
Peninsula Seafood Restaurant is a typical Cantonese seafood restaurant, which offers different kinds of seafood dishes. You can also eat all kinds of Dim Sum here. They offer Dim Sum all day, but the Dim Sum cart are only offered from 8am to 3pm. If you order Dim Sum during the Dim Sum cart time, the prices of all kinds of Dim Sum are cheaper. Beyond the Dim Sum cart time, the Dim Sum are a little bit expensive. I like the Dim Sum here so much, especially the shrimp noodle rolls and the cold chicken feet. I have eaten different kinds of shrimp noodle rolls and chicken feet in other restaurants and I think here is my favorite.

 It was my third time eating here. I ordered the steamed shrimp dumplings, the shrimp noodle rolls and the cold chicken feet. The steamed shrimp dumplings and the shrimp noodle rolls were piping hot. The shrimp noodle rolls were the best I've had and each piece had a large, tender shrimp blanketed with a silky soft layer of rice noodles. The taste was excellent and the cold chicken feet made me have a good appetite. 

The other important point for me to come back again is their service. Their service is fast and enthusiastic. The servers were extremely nice and friendly. I also got two-hour parking validated sticker which is super awesome and surprising because parking in Chinatown is a big hassle.
author: Cimin C.

description:
Was visiting SanFran, and decided I needed to get some Dim Sum for dinner.  Originally, I was gonna go to Delicious Dim Sum with someone staying at the hostel I was in, but for some reason it was closed.  At 7 pm.  Weird

We sat down after a 5 minute wait, and we ordered 4 dishes (5 counting my cup of Hot & Sour Soup). Specifically, they were the Peking Duck, Sweet & Sour Chicken, Prawns on Tender Greens (Bok Choy), and Pork with Garlic.

First the not-so-good news.  These servings are big; don't go in there unless you have a serious appetite.The Pork with Garlic was very bland.  I was expecting a sharp little kick of garlic-y goodness, and it wasn't there.  We waited around half an hour for them to give us the bill, to the point where we had to ask them to give us our bill.  A little strange service, but otherwise fine.

Now the good news.  I've never really tasted Hot & Sour soup quite like this: VERY hot, nice touches of sour flavor, and a thick broth.  The Sweet & Sour Chicken was slightly better than average, nothing to praise. The prawns were nice, and the bok choy was steamed perfectly.  However, the star of the show was the Peking Duck.  Very juicy, lightly fried, and it came with these sticky buns which the duck paired perfectly with.

Overall, it was a nicely-priced restaurant which, while having a little strange service, made up for it by its generous portions and excellent cooking.  I will be back.
author: Ben S.

description:
I was in Chinatown with my 9 year old and he wanted some Chinese food. We looked around at the pictures and he picked this place. 
We were the only customers in the restaurant. My boy wanted a whole fried fish, so there wasn't one on the menu, but they did one for him anyway. I've always wanted to try Peking Duck, and got that. Both dishes were greasy, but it's fish and duck so you kinda expect that. 
Place is kinda ran down, but presentable. Server was friendly.
author: David A.

description: It was a late night Monday (past 9pm), we took a chance and walked in. We ordered Fried Prawns,Fillet Rock Cod in Black Bean Sauce and Mongolian beef. We all agreed that the food was full of flavor and very delicious! Reasonable prices. Service was good but they forgot to come back with another dish we requested. No big deal since we were fully satisfied and didn't get charged for it. We will return!
author: B R.

description: Looked all over for a dim sum place on a holiday and so many places were closed! Finally settled in here, asked if they served dim sum when the waiter greeted us. He didn't answer, just waved us over to the table. Asked again, he grunted, so I assumed yes. He brought over plates, chopsticks (mine was a little dirty) and tea. He also dropped a piece of paper so you could circle what you wanted to order for dim sum. The lunch menu looked extensive but we didn't order anything off of it. The food was good, nothing too spectacular although the har gow was pretty yummy! We asked for wooden chopsticks since I wasn't too stoked to use the ones they gave me. The one waiter there doesn't really answer questions or converse much, but everything we did ask for, he brought. Not sure if I'd come back here, maybe if everything is closed again. (Don't use the bathrooms unless you absolutely have to!)
author: Day M.

description:
Was with my family from out of town and we were looking a Dimsum a place.  We decided to try this place as it looked decent and clean. We figured how can you go wrong on Chinese food in China town right??? 

We ordered a few dimsum items and a few plate items and none of them tasted  any good.  We spent over $100 for a group of 8 people and left feeling like we've been robbed.

We all hoped that the peking duck we ordered would be good, but  that did not come out as expected either. Too fatty!  Just like all the items served here, everything was flat out horrible.
author: Reymond R.

description:
Well our relationship started out rough, but ended well. 
 After being litterly passed by on several occasions, I finally stopped a server with dim sum and was served. After the initial start, the service was good. 
 I started today with pork rice noodle. Notice I didn't say bbq pork rice noodle. I ask the server when they offered it and they said pork. Maybe it was maybe it wasn't. Doesnt matter. It was a different and unique twist on the traditional bbq rice noodle dish. It wasn't bbq pork, but maybe pork and it was ground to the texture of maybe a potsticker. The mixture had vegis in it as well. Hard to explain,  but I really enjoyed this dish. Very different
Next steam bbq pork bun.  It was  good as well with big chunks of bbq pork. Not the traditional pink bbq pork but still very sweet. 
Sui mai. Good not spectacular,  but good
Hom soi gok, one of my favorites when made properly was tasty. Not super hot, more like room temperature. This is hit or miss, some serve it hot, which is how I like, and some serve it cold. Either way it was average.
author: James T.

description: Compared to the restaurant we went to last night, which only served tourists, this restaurant was PACKED with locals. We had to wait 20 minutes to be seated, and the restaurant is actually really big inside. The servers carry the dim sum around on trays, and we were able to taste a good variety of dim sum. A popular dish here that we saw many of the tables eating was the snails.. escargot.. or whateva they called. But we just got typical dim sum fare. I've said before, but Chinese food all tastes the same to me, and if you're an easy-going eater like me, you won't be disappointed by this place. Fast service, good food, reasonable prices. What more can you ask for??
author: Tricia M.

description: Second time we have been here and not disappointed.  The best dim sum I chinatown in my opinion.  The largest selection of dim sum.  99% Chinese patrons.  Best Chinese comfort food.
author: Anne P.
Kirsten K.

description:
Peninsula Seafood Restaurant...a Hong-Kong style restaurant that can compete with some of the legends of NYC's Chinatown.

The BBQ Pork Egg Foo Young is as close to perfect as one can get.  The ratio of pork to egg to bean sprouts to onions was magical.  And the sauce was light and didn't drown out the flavor.

The Chinese Broccoli in Oyster Sauce is a bit intense at first, so I suggest mixing the sauce into the broccoli to even out the flavor.  A little bit of water to dilute the intensity of the oyster sauce is highly recommended.  With any luck, there will be enough water at the bottom of the plate to mix with the oyster sauce.

The Young Chow Fried Rice was a bit disappointing.  I expected bigger chunks of meat.  It also needed a bit more salt.  The best Young Chow I've ever had can be found at Wo-Hop (NYC).  At Wo-Hop, the fried rice comes with bits of fried egg.  I assumed that the ingredients for Young Chow were standard.  Perhaps the fried egg is an anomaly?

In any event, I was pleased overall with the experience.  Our server was supremely attentive.  We were the only guests in the entire restaurant at 9pm on a Saturday night.  That weirded me out at first, but the food was delicious; which allayed my fears.

Give it a try...
author: Nino R.

description: This place serves really good daily dim sum for a great price.  Each dish is about $9 or less.  I would go for either: dim sum, seafood fried noodles, or mushu pork.  If you come at the right time, you can get seated right away.  On weekends, there's a long line that extends outside the restaurant.
author: Buortau L.

description: This place was ass. We found a pubey hair on our food plate! You could see the follicle! Plates were expensive, little portions,  and service was terrible! They didnt even offer us glasses of water! BUT i will say that their eggplant dish was really good. Other than that, they need to work on their service and sanitation because like they say, "you can tell how clean a restaurant is by their bathroom ". In other words, money NOT well spent. Bleh!
author: Jo Z.

description: Crowded and the service is horrible. The food isn't bad though. You have to be really aggressive here. No one was even at the front managing the wait/line. I wouldn't come here if you are a tourist.
author: Sarah C.

description: Won't be coming back. No service, waiter shouting over your head and worst of all passing dishes over your head too. Noisy and tables are placed too close together. Getting the attention of a waiter is like catching a fly, it sees you taunt you and fly away. Just horrible experience.
author: Susana T.

description: Too bad! The services was so bad, they acted like they dont care about you! i waited about 5 minutes at the front ..NOBODY host! They pointed they table for us to sit from far away!!! They were not that busy at all... They ignored me when i tried to called them that i'm ready to ordered!!!...food is bad and the place is not clean good, too!
author: Kieu T.

description:
Came here on a Sunday at around 1:30pm. My family of four decided to try this place since there was a small line wait of about 15 min compared to the 30-45 min line at the Greater Eastern Restaurant two doors down. 

I was honestly disappointed in the lack of variety of dim sum dishes that were going around. You had at most the same 4-5 waitresses carrying around trays of hot dim sum dishes in the entire restaurant. We were sitted in the back room near the corner so by the time the waitresses got around to us, there was only 1-2 plates left of dim sum on their tray. What's worse is that by the time the lunch crowd died out a little, we started to see the same type of dim sum waitress after waitress. Braised chicken feet after braised chicken feet after pork buns after pork buns. After we had ordered only 9 dim sum dishes, we sat there for a good 20-30 minutes waiting to see if they would bring out anything else. THEY DIDNT. It was the same braised chicken feet, pork buns, and a couple vegetable dumplings that no one wanted. After the long wait, we decided to leave very unsatisfied! 

As for the quality of the food, we had a couple of the shrimp dumplings, tofu skin wrapped with mushrooms, the chinese meatballs, pork buns, and chicken feet. All were decent, but have had better.
author: Bao D.

description:
Service SUCKS here, no one seems to be paying attention and listening, had to ask the same question repeatedly!!! The taste for the food is just ok but certain food are cold, can you imagine 

Definitely not recommended!
author: Minion C.

description: Restaurant was at 75% capacity on a Saturday evening when there wasn't a big event such as wedding. For dinner, the four of us shared lobster with ginger scallions, half peking duck, walnut prawns and gai lan, and we were quite full.  Service was very attentive.  For the restrooms I had set my expectations fairly low, so I thought it was fairly manageable.
author: T D.

description: Great dim sum for a good price.  A lot of old timers come here. This is one of the few dim sum places in the Bay Area that is open early.  They open at 8am on Sundays.
author: Geraldine S.

description:
The first time I walked straight past this place, looking for the dim sum place I had been going to for the past 22 years of my life called "Pearl City". My family was shocked to see that this place was no longer open, and instead, Peninsula Seafood Restaurant was in its place. My heart dropped, but we were still hopeful that maybe the owner changed but the chef would be the same.

Walked in, took a number, the usual at dim sum restaurants on a busy day. The dim sum was mediocre, definitely worse than its predecessor. But the one thing that was (still) amazing, was the rice baked in a clay pot, with Chinese dried meats and sausage on top. Sorry but the English name does not make it sound appetizing, but please take my advice--its incredible. I don't even like rice and I'm pretty sure I ate more than 3 servings of it.
author: Chrissy H.

description: Best Chinese food I've had so far in Frisco! My parents where visiting me for the weekend and they wanted to eat Chinese food seeing as they heard it was the best out there. Anyway the food was amazing hence the four stars. Service could have been better so I took a star for that but I would def come eat here again! Maybe takeout next time though...
author: Kareena R.

description:
Best chicken chow mein in SF's Chinatown.
Am I really the only reviewer to give Peninsula 5 stars? Yes I am!
Wel...l the food I received was very good, and the wait staff was superb.
A++
author: Jerry B.

description: Meeh. I liked this place more last year. Service was slow. We got seated in the middle. By the time fresh food came out, it got gobbled up by the larger tables at the back. They don't do the traditional HK style dimsum service with carts, so it's hard to get variety. I asked for the dimsum menu to hand pick stuff, but they completely ignored me and gave it to another table...I don't think I will be returning next time I'm in town.
author: Debbie C.

description:
Looking for a great taste of authentic Cantonese cuisine after a tiring stroll in Chinatown? A clean restaurant with tidy and prompt service? Look no further. I've been here a number of times and I can easily say that I am a big fan. 

First off, I would like to admit that I know the owner/manager's daughter fairly well and that is how I first heard about this place. However, I'd like to point out that it in no-way, shape or form affected my judgement upon writing this review. This place has great food, an awesome atmosphere, and a hardworking staff of individuals who want to make sure you are served in a timely and proper manner.

Breakfast happy hour, I like to call it, also known as dim sum time is absolutely busy at this place. Old Chinese men sharing stories of the pre-communist old country, populated families with young kids being chased around by their persevering parents, and non-regulars, like you and me, who are just looking to try out something new after trekking down and up hill all day around Chinatown just about sums up the daily demographic profile of patrons. The one thing we have in common? We'd all have love good Chinese food if we ended up here. The Dim Sum menu is fantastic and very fairly priced. I'm a fan of their shrimp dumplings and braised eggplant. I find that a lot of Chinese restaurants tend to overcook and over-season their eggplant to make up for the fact that it may be aged a little too wisely and Peninsula Seafood cooks it just right - fresh, not soggy, and with just the perfect amount of seasoning.

This review would not be complete without throwing in a shout-out to their honey walnut shrimp, which may just about worth visiting just to try. I live 40 minutes away in Sunnyvale, and I would take a drive right now just to grab myself some. 

All in all, this is a first-class restaurant that cooks great food and doesn't cut any corners when it comes to their food prep and service. I've eaten at a lot of good Chinese restaurants and was raised associating a stigma against Chinatown restaurants for having greasy and sodium enriched food paired with deliberately sluggish service. Peninsula Seafood Restaurant consistently proves me wrong and I'm always a happy customer.

On a somewhat unrelated note, if my review somehow influenced you to pay this deserving restaurant a visit, be sure to keep an eye out for a pretty girl in her early 20's named Courtni who works there and tell her Nick sent you ;)
author: Nick N.

description: The food was amazing! My favorites were the spare ribs and the chicken feet. Everyone was so nice to my party and I. I would definitely recommend this place.
author: Krystal L.

description: We really enjoyed this restaurant. All the waiters were fast, generous and Mr. Wong was extremely nice., Always smiling and answering all our questions. The food tastes amazing and we ordered the deluxe dinner for four and it was soooo delicious and also the serving sizes are large, very good for the whole family, we even had left overs and ate a lot. We left the restaurant with big smiles. We will come back here for sure. Thank you for making our dinner such a great experience. I highly recommend this place.
author: Martha C.

description: been to this place for many many years, it was remodeled I think couple years ago which makes the dining experience much better(before remodeling it was pretty run down), it is my go to place in Chinatown for dimsum, I would not go to any other ones. All their food is authentic Hong Kong/Guangdong style. The owner always talk to us and the other regulars whenever he has time to, very rare quality in this business these days.
author: Jordan D.

description: Was in Chinatown on an errand, stopped in here for some dim sum. Wow, I had no idea how bad food could be prepared and served. Flavorless, greasy, completely lackluster food, served by bored, completely uncommunicative waiters. Left 5% tip, because I know how difficult making a living in this city can be. Will not EVER return. Please if you value your tastebuds, don't even send your worst enemy's dog to this restaurant!
author: Doug W.

description: Ordered two dishes (forgot their English names). Was told need to wait for 20 minutes, however, I actually waited for 40 minutes. They gifted me a steam cabbage for the delay, which is fine. But the dishes were not very good for the price. I think they should put more oyster in the egg, and much much more meat, not rice.
author: Andrew L.

description: If I could give zero stars I would. Half way through dim sum they decided to end service while half the food I ordered had still not shown. If I order the food before service ends and are able to receive half the food, why couldn't I get the other half! Not clean. Dust on the walls. Took 20 min to even put the order in. Servers bumping into me at the table. Don't go. Take 5 min to find a better restaurant.
author: Nicholas T.

description:
I'm a China Town neophyte with an amateur badge when it comes to dim sum.  I came here while visiting some friends in San Francisco and was surprised at how good it was.

First off, all the ingredients tasted super fresh.  Then the calamari and scallops that came with some of the noodle dishes literally melted in your mouth.  The typical fried dim sum didn't ooze oil and you can tell they just cooked it right before it came to your table.  

Frank, the manager was very personable and attentive.  Too bad he wasn't contagious cause the other servers could have used his pizzazz.  

It's been hours since I've had their food and I'm still thinking about it.  I'm pretty sure I'll be having food dreams about it tonight.

The End
author: Lizette A.

description: Food was ok and not worth the hassle of going into Chinatown for.  EXTREMELY SLOW service.  It took us over 35 minutes to get any food.
author: Lalu B.

description: I would not even give this place a one because it was a terrible experience. Mongolian beef spicy..... My dry green beans dish was spicier then that.  Food is mediocre at best slightly below Panda Express at least there the food is serve hot. She adds her own tip to every order what she thinks she deserves... Go figure that. I thought tips were based on your service to the guests. In this case she should have paid my family to eat here. If you complain about the time it takes to get your order right the same response " Sit down and it is cooking" hmmm never been told that before, if it is cooking then why does my order show up and Luke warm at best. Her daughter is sitting at another table with friends and everything is delivered to her sizzling and having steam coming from it. Terrible experience do not go here try cooking t home because at least you know it will be hot and flavorful.
author: Christopher Y.

description:
Gone are the women wait staff replaced by men who swear  alot amongst themselves, but within earshot...very inappropriate.

Dim Sum was average at best - it's predecessor was slightly better.

Regardless of name, my wife's grandmother still goes here weekly like timework.
author: Peter L.

description:
If they had Zero stars, this is it!
Waited today for a table (I know...Sunday in Chinatown). Took a number. 
One of the two lady hostess/owners passed us over for two parties (tourists) in front of our noses. 
Politely told her that we were ahead of them. 
Responded that they were sharing a table. Uh huh....Sure nuff...She took them to two separate tables and then came back and "reassured: me that our wait wasn't going to be too long.
If they can lie so easily in front of you, just think what they do behind your back. Lying came too easy to them.
author: Art Y.

description: Giving a one star is already too much to me... My English is not that good but hope u guys can understand what m I trying to say. The food was ok but this is the baddest service ever! Probably I'm Chinese too so that's why ppl are not Chinese thinks is pretty good.
author: Cat Y.

description:
Came here for Dim Sum lunch on a late Saturday afternoon and surprisingly it was not that crowded as I was expecting.

Service was ok, took awhile to serve us water, but they were swift with the hot tea!

You would expect your typical dim sum items- dumplings, meat steam buns, chicken feet, seafood items, dessert, etc. 

I really wanted to like this place but it did not wow me. There was about 5 people pushing the food carts, but of many of the same items. It was hard to find any green leaves dishes. Possibly we should have waited for dinner :/
author: Wendee H.

description:
Pricing: Good. Not too sure since my father and uncle "fought for the bill."
Quality: Good-Excellent. The glutinous rice dim sum was on the spot, but everything else was standard.
Turnaround: Excellent. They were still doing the trays of dim sum after 1pm!
Service: Good. A little sparse since they seated us in the back

A look at the menu told me that the food was very standardly priced according to Chinatown prices, but I never got a look at the final bill since coming from an Asian family means the older relatives will always be fighting for the bill after the meal. The dim sum was pretty standard with the usual chicken feet, spareribs, and whatnots. Then we had an order of shrimp dumplings and the rice "skin" was excellent. Just the right thickness and transparency such that it wrapped the shrimps inside perfectly without tearing apart or being too thick and chewy in the mouth. When the rice crepes came, I realize that this restaurant just does excellent work with the glutinous rice dim sum. We had came in after 1pm so I was expecting the dim sum to die down with nothing much to eat, but instead, they were still continuously wheeling out trays of dim sum. Not to mention, when asked, they were willing to make new orders for us. Of course, since they sat us in the back room, unless we ordered directly, not a lot of trays come by for us to just take the food off.
author: Jenny W.

description:
We were really happy to find this place last weekend, we remember going a few years ago but forgot the name.  Almost everything we got was great.  Spring rolls, roast duck, pork buns, su mai, chinese broccoli, pot stickers, sesame puffs.  The only thing that was so so was the soy sauce lo mein, it was kind of blah and if not for the spicy chili sauce on the table wouldn't have been much of anything.  It was nice having a pot of tea on the table too.  Lots of places don't provide tea anymore.

The service was better than other dim sum places we've been to, we were seated quickly even though arrived around noon on Saturday.  We never waited long to see food being walked by, but they were not pushy about it like some other places.  The place also was nicer & cleaner than some we've been to.

We liked having the option to order from the dim sum menu in addition to picking from the trays, and although there was somewhat of a language barrier we were able to talk to some of the folks, and when we asked if there were other duck dishes available than on the menu they told us the options.  This is way better than other places where you just get funny looks if you try talking with them!   

They also honored the sign in the window and credited us for 2 hours of parking in the nearby deck, and quickly took care of our check when we were ready.  

We'll definitely go back.
author: D R.

description:
Goal: 
1. Awesome birthday party for my man's 30th.
2. Dim sum at night
3. BYOB

Peninsula Seafood accomplished all of these things! The food was better than expected (good dim sum, good duck). The birthday boy is a dim sum snob, but was pleasantly surprised by this place. The food was good, not amazing, but good. The service was wonderful and the english-speaking female manager made all of our birthday wishes come true. It's only a $10 corkage fee, they kept our ice cream cake cool in their freezer, and even came and sang happy birthday at the end. Best part, the tab was only ~20 bucks a person for huge dinner feast!

Thank you Peninsula Seafood for making our celebration super fun, tasty, affordable, and easy to plan!
author: Rebecca W.

description: Worst place ever! This is a cheating and illegal operation. The food is aweful and we asked for the receipt but they refused. They also tip themselves 20% when charge my credit card. This place doesnt pay tax to our government and should be shut down. Totally illegal!!!! Plus the service is aweful. Sucks!
author: Meggie N.

description: Omg, best place in Chinatown and very inexpensive.  Adventurous food, great service, and authentic dim sum.  Loved it!
author: Daniel F.

description:
I will give 0 star if it's an option. 

WARNING: PEOPLE WHO'S TAKING A BABY WITH YOU, STAY AWAY FROM THEM! THEY WILL YELL AT YOU IF YOU HAVE A STROLLER!

So last week I went to Chinatown with my parents. My mom always like going there to get fresh grocery so I took my 10 months old son and went there. 

We stopped by this stupid place and decided to have dim sum before shopping. AND IT WAS A MISTAKE! we didn't might a 40 min wait, that's what it is. The hostess told us she will give us a midium size round table so we have room for our baby and the stroller. Guess what? When she called us in, it was a retangular table for 4 by the walk way, then the waitress (I guess she's the manager or owner), started screaming to me: how can you bring a stroller here! There's no room for it! And I was so shocked!!! Then I asked can I keep it next to the table? She kept screaming: Don't you ever think of other people? They won't be able to walk by!!! And I was like WTF!!! People sitting around was staring at us...And it was so uncomfortable!!! Then the bixch offered us the "midium size table" (that was what the hostess offered at the very beginning!), and we sat it. I didn't want to argue with her while my baby and my parents were there.

I was SOOOOOOOOOOOOO mad! How can these axxholes stay in business? I was gonna complaint that bixch and I looked at their counter, now I get it, she has so many picture hanging on the wall, she must be a manager or owner.

We ate, and we left. And I know I won't ever go back to this stupid place in rest of my life.

There's no manner, no managerment in this place. While I was waiting,I heard the hostess talking to waiters inside via walkie talkie: ok 2 are coming, one man one woman.....and there's another 2, guai lou..... They have no respect to their customers.

The one next door is always so much busier than this place, I guess that's the reason. 

Oh I almost forgot, this place is definitely BAD for infants, there's no place to change a diaper for my baby and I had to go to the bathroom with my mom, I held the baby and mom took care of the rest. No changing table! And the bathroom is sooo gross! 

Ok, I feel better now.
author: T J.

description:
Dim sum here soothed the ache in my west LA-dwelling heart.  Stuck with mostly veggie fare (wu gok, lo bak go, spring rolls, etc.) with some shrimp (ha gow) thrown in,  for the sake of my pescetarian dining companion.  They were out of dan tat, but their char siu bao made me want to roll myself up inside and weep for what I was missing down south.

We did tack on an order of gai lan (Chinese broccoli) to fill out the meal a bit, but this was meh-worthy, swimming in oil with too much oyster sauce.  Service was about what you'd expect with authentic dim sum; at least they dropped off a handful of napkins without a word when my friend spilled sauce all over her half of the table.
author: Bethany T.

description: Ate at this restaurant this past weekend with my friends and boyfriend, the food was pretty good but the experience as a whole was not all that satisfying. First as we walked in, we were literally the only customers in the entire restaurant which left us wondering. Also, the police came in while we were eating and that was a tiny bit unsettling, as they were not there to eat. Also, my boyfriend found a hair in his food, which needless to say was quite disgusting. Then when the bill came they add the tip for  you in the bill...what if I didn't find the service tip worthy? Also, kind of screwing yourselves because what if I wanted to add a higher tip? hmmm. Also, the place was kind of a mess, there was stuff and crumbs all over the floor that they were sweeping up. Also, when my friend and I went to the restroom the gentleman cleaning it was overdoing it with the mopping, I mean EVERYTHING WAS SO WET, almost to the point where we were sliding around.
author: Krisa M.

description: Absolutely .The Worst. Chinese Food.  If you want slimy prawns, inedible fish soup, bad chicken, bland sauces, try it at your own risk.  Otherwise, stay away!!!  I was sick all night after dining there.  If would not go back if they offered me $$$.
author: Irena P.

description: We will never come back to this restaurant because we did not care for the poor quality of the meat.  The soups, even the hot and sour, tasted strongly of fish, so much that I could not finish my cup.  The chicken would have been rejected by even the most polite diner if you ask me, and overall, they will have to greatly improve to compete in Chinatown.
author: Mark P.

description: The manfriend and I were wandering Chinatown around 8pm on a weeknight looking for a good place to eat.  I was looking at the photos of the different foods on the window and a young waiter came outside and started speaking to me in Chinese.  I asked him in English if they made walnut shrimp, and he said yes.  So I dragged the manfriend inside and we ordered the walnut shrimp and a green bean dish.  The lady manager(?) was very nice and also gave us each a bowl of the soup of the day on the house.  The walnut shrimp was delicious and the beans were good.  It was pretty empty in there but it seemed more people started showing up when we rolled out of there happy and full.
author: Francesca K.

description: The place was great. East to get to from the hotel we were staying at (Triton) and we were seated quickly. Looked pretty clean and people very nice. Definitely not pricey, we had Dim Sum and we had a LOT for under $27. Service is very fast. Great selection. I'm not Chinese but loved their stuff.
author: Mo A.

description: I don't even want to give one star to the restaurant. We waited almost 1 and half hour after the first three dishes were served. And they don't even show any sorry feelings. The food was not good either.
author: Jie Y.

description: Do not be fooled by the old generation locals that you see sitting in the front dining area!!  THE FOOD IS REALLY BAD! the worst dim sum in my whole entire life!!  The shrimp dumpling (har gow), skin is thick and over cooked, the pork siew mai has zero flavor,  The rice paper roll (churn fun) rice paper was soooooooo thick + no flavor.   After the 3 dishes that came, I picked my arse up paid the bill and left.   Trust me.. the food is horrible!
author: Jan Y.

description: I came early- service overall was good. Food was pretty bland, nothing spetacular. It's actually worst than it used to be... I was debating to give them a 1 star, but to good service. They deserve a 2!
author: Monika T.

description:
9 o' clock in the morning on a tuesday and we're wandering around chinatown, seeing the sights, doin' the touristy thang, and of course, lookin' for some awesome grub.  since it was so dang early and nothing opens 'til like 11AM, this place was recommended to us by one of the local tea shops where we stopped for some boba milk tea.

we walk into the restaurant and all i see are local chinese folks.  how do i know?  not a single one of them looks like a tourist.  =)  and every single one of them is staring at us like "what the fcuk are you tourists doing in our locals-only place??"  =)

anyway, we sit down...and wait...and wait...and wait.  finally some dimsum comes around, but it's only like 2-3 options that a lady is carrying around on a tray.  at least in so-cal dimsum, all the food is on steam carts and what-not.  anyway, not liking the 2-3 options she had, we waited for more to come out.  and waited.  and waited.  funny thing is- it seems like everyone else is waiting for more food too!  i could tell because i kinda speak the language (keyword there is "kinda"), and i could tell by the tone of their voice- they weren't too happy about it, and were certainly takin' it out on the wait staff.

long story short- we had 2 orders of pork shu-mai, 2 orders of ha-gow, 1 order of black bean spareribs, and 1 order of lo mai gai.  6 dishes and total was $23 out-the-door.  

food was decent, but dang the service completely bombed!  i guess it you had A TON of time to sit around and wait, you could try hanging out here long enough to try a bit of everything.  but since we were on a clock, we didn't have much time to waste.  anyway, good luck to ya if you decide to try this place...
author: Hung-wei L.

description: I am not a huge dim sum fan but this place was good and the service was great. We went here for my buddies birthday and ate our hearts out and it was only $25 each with tip which I could not believe. Har gow was good, shu mai was my favorite. Mongolian beef was also good.
author: Ryan S.

description: I came here with family and friends and the food was tasteless and over cooked.  The walnut shrimp was soggy. Egg flower soup what is just plain water with cornstarch. I asked for spicy mongolian beef, horrible. I don't think I'll be coming back and visit anytime soon
author: Mike K.

description: Very authentic ambiance - felt like I was in Hong Kong once again, surrounded by locals and being offered chicken feet. True, no Chinese ladies yelled at us like in Hong Kong, but that is more of a plus :)
author: Lena R.

description:
Although their food is okay, their service was horrible. I ate here with family a few times and usually we would be one of maybe five tables in the restaurant. This time, it was New Years Eve so more people came out to eat dinner. Their menu consists of all the cliche Chinese dishes and dishes that seem like they made it up on the top of their heads. Their pricing is outrageous for the small amount of food for each dish. And guess what? The table next to us got the same dish as us and they got 2x as much. Apparently, the owners know them and got better treatment than the rest of the people in the restaurant. Is this restaurant a business or a home kitchen where you whip out more extravagant dishes for your friends and relatives?? The table behind us ordered when we were halfway done eating. When we were done eating, they STILL didn't get their food yet. I overheard them ordering a set meal, and usually Chinese people order different dishes so I guessed they take longer to make the set meals. They were tourists from a foreign country, I can't be sure if that has to do with anything... But really, they didn't get their food even after 30 minutes... I think someone needs to tell their waiters that they shouldn't rudely talk about their co-workers when in front of customers. 

So long story short: OVER PRICED, RUDE SERVICE, NOTHING SPECIAL ABOUT THE FOOD
author: Angela H.

description: The only reason I come here is because of my dad and grandmother. I'm guessing the owner changed, so some of the waiters/waitresses rose up in rank now. Last time I came here we didn't have many selections. The food itself is not bad, but service is horrible. Tablecloth is disgusting and I've never gone back to the restroom after I went in there couple years ago. When we left I noticed that all the good dishes were being served in the front of the restaurant.
author: Artisha C.

description: I don't recommend this place. We really wanted dim sum in Chinatown. After looking for a long time on Yelp, we "settled" on this place because we were starving. They were turning over from lunch first off, so there were only two other parties there at the time. The carpet needed to be vacuumed horribly. The table clothes, filthy. The waiter was not too excited to help us. So we ordered some food, and what came out was very greasy, and just not good dim sum as compared to other places i've tried. Skip this one when you're in Chinatown. The other small, hole-in-the-wall looking places are apparently better.
author: Kerri B.

description: Foods good, prices are fair but a little on the higher side for Chinatown. Descent service.
author: Jen L.

description: We visited late afternoon after attending a Giants game. The restaurant was almost empty, as it was between standard mealtimes. We were thrilled that it was open. The food was very good and reasonable. The service was a bit slow. The only problem we ran into was using our Restaurant.com voucher. Participating restaurants are supposed to accept either a paper or an onscreen voucher (they just note the voucher number), but the waiter and manager insisted they needed a paper copy. Restaurant.com will follow up with them, but I suggest you bring a paper copy. Following our conversation with the waiter and manager about the voucher they disappeared, which made ordering difficult. We also found an item on the bill we had never received, so check your bill carefully.
author: Johanna W.

description: Decent dim sum at pretty reasonable prices, though nothing stood out.  I'd say the shrimp-based dishes are the best here and tasted freshest. It was also on the oily side, even for dim sum, though I ate everything I ordered, oil and all.
author: Josh Q.

description:
I've eaten at about every restaurant in Chinatown so when I saw this place with a "grand opening" sign, I had to check it out.  Ironically I did not try any seafood or dim sum (the two things everyone has reviewed and what the restaurant advertises).  Instead I went with the chicken pan fried noodles, the Peking spare ribs, and general chicken.  

I can say the chicken (which was fried) is some of the best I've had.  It was crispy on the outside and really light/fluffy on the inside.  The sauce wasn't the best ever but it was still good.  The spare ribs were a lot of bone and little meat, but still good.  The noodles did not have any bok choy, which was a let down and it caused the noodles to be a bit on the bland side.  

As previous reviews alluded to, the wait staff is about what you should expect from Chi-town...not the most attentive in the world, but they bring you your food quickly and are good enough to tip 20%.

Huge portion sizes, cheap prices, good food.  A solid four star restaurant.  Will definitely go back for more food in the future.
author: A W.

description: Nice food, extremely poor service. Some Chinese travel agencies take their tourist groups to this place, so the restaurant don't seem to worry about lack of customers. They were quite offensive whey they talked to us. The price is higher than other dim sum places I have been to.
author: Paul L.

description: If a negative ranking is available that is what I want to give to this place.  Worst service.  My family of four signed in at 11:10am on a Saturday morning, noting there were 3~4 groups ahead of us on the sign-in sheet.  We waited for 30 minutes still didn't get a table!  While we waited at the entrance, many groups were seated, but not us!  People came in later than us were giving smaller numbers and were seated in front of our face!  Those people spoke Cantonese.  If you don't speak Cantonese, don't go there.  You will be treated awfully.  Bring your business to many other fine restaurants in Chinatown.  We left after realizing what went on.
author: Charlene S.

description: The dim sum was amazing.  Ask for the dim sum menu and the waiters are very helpful in pointing out what they are brining around.  Don't be put off by the lack of reviews...something tells me the local/regular cliental aren't yelpers.
author: Allie B.

description: The food was better than I thought it would be! The overall look is very deceiving but when that food came out...man...that's all that mattered! Shrimp seemed fresh (but I'm not the best at determining that) and the peking duck was perfect. Like everyone says the service was pretty slow, I completely agree, but I'm a patient person so it's no big deal to me.
author: Maurice L.

description: Do you want to be treated like a second-class citizen? Then this is your place. We  were almost completely ignored by the waitresses circulating the Dim Sum. Tray after tray were taken to the same family groups over and over again, leaving them with nothing for our table. During the hour and 15 minutes we were there we were lucky enough to get a couple of dumplings (which were flavorful), but we were still starving when we finally paid the check and went somewhere else that would actually serve us food.
author: Brian A.

description: What a find!  Everyone knows that all the good dim sum places are in South Bay, so I was very nervous about randomly walking into a place in C-town.  Luckily, 99% of the people occupying the restaurant were Chinese.  We ordered your typical dim sum fare - steamed buns, spare ribs, dumplings, turnip cake, etc.   Everything was solid.
author: Christine L.

description: I, like some of the other reviewers, was looking for Pearl City. We went on a Sunday for dim sum. Got laughed at for asking for a fork, which pissed me off. So the bf isn't comfortable with chopsticks...whatever. The dim sum was ok, not bad, not great. Three dishes came to abt 12.00, so how can you beat that? My real issue came when I paid with a credit card and the cashier  - the manager, owner- kept insisting, "Service not included, service not included!" How would she know if I left  the tip on the table or not? I tried to move out of the way and dig in my purse for a few dollars while she is still repeating it over and over, like I'm going to run off. Yeah, so I'm cheap, but does being treated rudely and having them come to my table a few times count as good service?
author: mary b.

description: My three friends and I decided to venture in here during our vacation to eat dim sum. They require you to fill out a paper and check the items you would like to eat. After they give you a plate, they stamp another paper ( the bill) and calculate at the end. We were not paying attention to the stamps the waiters were entering. Upon getting our final bill it was $100 for the 4 of us! We reconciled the paper against the bill and the number of checks did not tie out. When we tried to argue with the manager, he said that he doesn't look at the paper with the checks and only calculates based on the bill and that it doesn't matter if they don't tie. It was completely ridiculous. After arguing for 5 minutes, my friends gave up and we paid the bill and left. We are completely annoyed that we got ripped off on vacation at dim sum. Plus the food was only subpar!!! If you want good dim sum, go to NYC. It's cheaper, delicious and they don't have a two paper system to rip you off!!!
author: Stephanie T.

description: This review is for dim sum only.  I went in with a friend with a mad dumpling craving, so we went to Peninsula (based on Yelp reviews) and we weren't disappointed (although we knew we wouldn't be, once we saw that we were probably the only English-speaking customers there).  Everything we had was pretty good, but especially good were the baked bbq pork buns, siu mai, and beef meatballs.  Service was pretty good for a Chinese place, and after we ate ourselves silly, the bill was only $27.  They lose a star though because the food came out a bit slow, and they didn't have a couple things we wanted, but I'll definitely go back in the future.
author: Pilan C.

description: For a Chinatown restaurant, this is actually really really good dim sum.  The service, as you would expect for Chinatown, wasn't super attentive, but we did get our water, hot water refill, forks, etc.  The shrimp dumpling, pork dumpling and chow mein were really good.  You know if the chow mein (HK style) is good if you don't see a puddle of oil at the bottom of the noodle plate.  Prices are very reasonable - six people left the restaurant with a total bill (including tip) of $70 and we were all really full.
author: Jay S.

description: I'm giving this place 3.5 stars, we went for a work lunch, the place is huge and seating wasn't a problem for our group of 6 right at noon. There was a good variety of food options and everything tasted good. I've definitely had better dim sum in downtown Oakland or down in the Peninsula. The place is still good and worth checking out, however I wasn't too fond of the service, but then again it's dim sum. I will acknowledge that the price is well worth the value, our entire bill was less than $80 and we had a ton of food for the 6 of us. I would definitely go back and I would recommend it to others.
author: mehul p.

description: My BBQ pork inside my rice noodle roll of dim sum was so burnt; and the black pepper rib was very unimpressive
author: Michelle K.

description: This is the 2nd time here . We ordered some dim sum and beef chow fun but both me and my friend got sick. I assume something not fresh.
author: TT P.

description: So many dim sum choices and so little time. Took my family and had a great Sunday brunch. Everything fresh and tasty.  I do not claim to be an expert but am experienced enough to know the difference and the dim sum here is really good. Pricing was fair and it is just as busy as the main tourist attraction next door.
author: John L.
